results.name: Essentials for Raising Money for Your Business – Workshop

results.description:
Srikrishna Sridhar

Brian Granger from the IPython/Jupyter project and Peter Wang from Continuum Analytics will be speaking at this PyData NYC meetup.  We will also have lightning talks and a short reception.  We are lucky to have very high-profile speakers - they are in town for the PyData session at the Strata+Hadoop conference.

Registration ends Tuesday, 29 Sep, at 4pm.  Time is very short to register, so please spread the word and register soon.  We are meeting in a secured building again, so you will need to bring photo ID to get a security badge (please answer the RSVP questions giving your name as it appears on the photo ID).

The rough schedule is:

• 6:00pm - Doors open


• 6:30pm - Speakers


• Srikrishna Sridhar

• Brian Granger

• Peter Wang

• Lightning Talks

• 8:00pm - Reception


• 9:00pm - Meetup ends


Speakers

Srikrishna Sridhar, Scaleable Time-Series Analysis using GraphLab Create.  There are many instances of data used for machine learning tasks that have a timestamp feature which provides an implicit temporal ordering on the observations, e.g., log data, sensor data, market data. Scaling up time-series related machine learning applications requires more scalable data structures.  In this talk, we apply scalable time series analysis in the energy sector on usage data from household appliances and smart homes.  Krishna has a PhD in Computer Science from University of Wisconsin-Madison where he worked on high-performance software for large scale problems in mathematical optimization, and data analysis. His work has been used in applications such as health care, industrial production planning, and machine learning.

Brian Granger, Mystery Night at PyData.  To keep things exciting, I will talk about a random topic related to Python and Data Science. This topic will likely be related to Project Jupyter, visualization or Data Science education. Brian is an Associate Professor of Physics and Data Science at Cal
Poly State University in San Luis Obispo, CA. He is a leader of the
IPython project, co-founder of Project Jupyter and is an active
contributor to a number of other open source projects focused on data
science in Python. He is a board member of the NumFOCUS Foundation and
a faculty fellow of the Cal Poly Center for Innovation and
Entrepreneurship.

One last thing: we've noticed a number of people registering and taking available seats, but then not coming to the event.  If you register and are unable to attend, please change your RSVP to a "No" so the seat is released to others who can come.
results.name: October PyData NYC meetup

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening 5K walk or run or C25K. Because we are meeting after most are getting out of work the pace will be more conversational.

There will be no bag check. If you need to check a bag please go to the Running Company Store located on the second floor of the Time Warner Center located in Columbus Circle, if you are meeting at the Central Park Entrance at Columbus Circle. If you are meeting at the 72nd Street Transverse (72nd Street inside the park, go to Jack Rabbit located at 140 W 72nd St. Bring a lock for your locker.

As with all of our workouts we will include ab and other workouts as well as stretches to enhance your performance.

Walkers and Runners will start out together. We will establish a point to meet up for workouts mid-way. The course we trek will depend on the interest and experience levels of all who join.

Please bring water with you to stay hydrated. We will provide RAP protein gummies for all who participate and Gevalia Kaffe Iced Coffee with Almond Milk after the work out courtesy of our sponsors.

If you are running late or need to cancel please contact an organizer as soon as possible. 3 no shows will lead to members being pulled out of the group.

If you have any questions please let us know.

We look forward to seeing you all!

Cheers to happy walks and runs!

Your sole sisters,
@JKORunning
results.name: Thursday Night Power Walk or Run

results.name: Essentials for Raising Money for Your Business – Workshop

group.name: People Looking to Start a Business

results.description:
Raising capital is difficult, complicated, frustrating and often will lead to failure. The tools and techniques you will acquire in this workshop may put you on the path to succeed!


Some of the many factors to consider are: Who will provide the money, how to find financing sources and how to make it happen -- Choosing a path to follow can be overwhelming. Facing the risks, costs and effort involved with raising capital, may make you hesitate to take the leap.


- What type of financing is best for your business? 

- Do you need new money, why, and what forms will be most appropriate?

- How do you find a funder?.. Where do you start looking? 

- What  do you need to have to satisfy an investor?

- What are the trade-offs among various funding alternatives?

Some of the topics will include: Getting ready for funding, What investors look for in companies, Venture Capital, Angels, Startup Financing, Microloans, Bank Loans, SBA, Royalty Financing, Grants, Peer-to-Peer lending, Initial Public Offering, SBIC, Crowdfunding and, where to find them!  


Some of the techniques are: Do's and Don'ts when pitching investors, What VC’s and Angels expect to know about your business, Getting ready for funding, Overcoming common obstacles, How to convince Investors.

This workshop will discuss the process of raising money, from the early development stage of financing to finding investors.

Do NOT miss this workshop designed to give you access to an unprecedented amount of knowledge and insights shared by Roger Kuperways, Ph.D., an industry insider, life-long entrepreneur, investor, mentor, business coach and adjunct professor of entrepreneurship -- He built a multi-million dollar empire from scratch and has many years of experience in a variety of businesses and industries. He also lectures at trade shows and corporate events on Business issues. The workshop is based on lectures given by Dr. Kuperways at New York University for more than 25 years.

Veterans Entrepreneurs Reception Meetup Mashup with Technology Transfer Days' ( http://www.meetup.com/Technology-Transfer-Days/ ) Veteran Entrepreneur's Reception and OWASPBrooklyn's Veterans in AppSec (VIA)

Speakers: 

Steven Kuyan

Channeling Military Skills to Incubator Startups 

Steven Kuyan is Managing Director of Incubators and Entrepreneurship at the NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering. He co-founded and is responsible for managing two of the three incubators located at Varick Street in Soho and DUMBO in Brooklyn. On campus, Steven develops strategic initiatives to accelerate innovation at the University through programs that catalyze student innovation. 

Kristen Matter is detailing as an assistant to the NYC Engagement Manager.  In this role, she work with innovators, entrepreneurs, and local educators in and around New York  City, providing them with appropriate information and resources offered by the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) and the Department of Commerce.

Ms. Matter is also currently a Primary Patent Examiner in the Pro Se Assistance Program. Before coming to the USPTO, Kristen worked at Nationwide Children’s Hospital in Columbus, Ohio, as a research assistant in the Center for Injury Research and Policy. Ms. Matter began her career at the USPTO in 2006 as a patent examiner and became a primary patent examiner in 2011. In 2008, Kristen moved to NYC to attend Fordham Law School part time while continuing in her role as a patent examiner. Ms. Matter is registered to practice law in Ohio and Washington, DC. Kristen received the Department of Commerce Bronze Medal Award for Superior Federal Service in 2013, and the American Intellectual Property Law Association Examiner Award in 2014. In addition to her J.D. from Fordham Law, Kristen received her Bachelor’s degree in Mechanical Engineering and Master’s degrees in Mechanical Engineering and Biomedical Engineering from The Ohio State University.

Arpan Savla is detailing as an assistant to the NYC Engagement Manager.  In this role, he works with innovators, entrepreneurs, and local educators in and around New York  City, providing them with appropriate information and resources offered by the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) and the Department of Commerce.

Mr. Savla began his career at the USPTO in 2005 and is currently a Primary Patent Examiner in the Computer Architecture and Software area.  Arpan graduated magna cum laude from Boston University in 2005 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering.

Ryan Letts, Brooklyn SBDC 

Veteran Entrepreneurs:

Pathfinder

DavinciBA

Core Leader

TripSafe

results.description:
Welcome to ORLCAPEX NYC's October 2015 meetup! This meetup will consist of several lightning talks that will be around 20 minutes each. We're still finalizing the content, but we wanted to create this event ASAP so that you could plan on attending. Here's what we have planned so far...

Josh Millinger will present on Integrating APEX and SQL Server.

Tim Chambers - Front End Builds in APEX: Application Express comes with tens of thousands of lines of CSS and JS: all of which has consistently and efficiently churned out with just a few commands. In this talk, managing complexity in build scripts will be covered by discussing the merits of frameworks like GruntJS and GulpJS and non-front end build scripts written in Python, Perl and Bash.

Dan McGhan - Custom UIs with JavaScript and APEX_JSON:  Generally speaking, it's best to use the native components (forms, reports, etc.) within APEX to build out applications. There are, of course, exceptions to this rule. Sometimes it's best to spend some extra development cycles to build a UI that provides a more targeted user experience. Luckily, a little JavaScript and some work with the new APEX_JSON package can go a long way! 

Marc Sewtz will present something awesome! 

Also, we'll be giving away a free copy of the recently released book: Expert Oracle Application Express, 2nd Edition. Hope to see you there! :)

Note: You must RSVP for this event and seats are limited. Please RSVP with your full name and bring matching ID for security. Please do not RSVP if you are unsure that you will be able to attend. If you do RSVP and are no longer able to attend please change your status so that someone on the waiting list may take your place.
results.how_to_find_us: South of Grand Central Terminal on the northwest corner of Park Ave and 41st Street.
results.name: ORCLAPEX NYC Meetup - October 2015

results.description:
This page has images of the openings we will be attending, so if you dont see them and you are........


1) viewing this page on the Meetup app click the description tab to view the list of galley openings.  

2) using an Android mobile browser open your browser's settings menu and click ''Request Desktop Site". 

3) using  Apple IOS then click the desktop site button at the bottom of the page. 

For those new to the Hop you might be wondering how you will find the group. Well below are two pictures of myself. Study my face carefully and commit it to memory. Now that I am burned into your hippocampus simply look for me hovering near the entrance of The Drawing Center.

The Adult Me

My Inner Child

Just a little more business...


Every week I receive emails from new members asking if there is a fee to join or attend the Thursday Night Gallery Hop. So rather than answer each email individually I'll kill a whole flock of birds with one stone.   


THE HOP IS, ALWAYS HAS BEEN, AND WILL REMAIN COMPLETELY FREE  


That said if you would like to help offset my organizer fees or buy me a post-hop bourbon you are more than welcome to click the 'chip in' button on the left side of this page. But let me reiterate contributions while appreciated are NOT required. 

And now the openings...


RichardPousette-Dart: 1930s

Best known as a founding member of the New York School of painting, Richard Pousette-Dart [masked]) initially pursued a career as a sculptor. The son of Nathaniel Pousette, a painter, art director, educator, and art writer, and Flora Louise Dart, a poet and musician, Pousette-Dart was raised in an environment surrounded by music, poetry, and the visual arts, and began drawing and painting by the age of eight. Introduced to African, Oceanic, and Native American art by his father, Pousette-Dart made frequent visits to the Museum of Natural History as a young man. In 1938, he forged a close friendship with John Graham, whose writings were closely aligned with his own interests in spiritual concerns and so-called primitive art. Throughout the 1930s, Pousette-Dart was most entranced by the work of Henri Gaudier-Brzeska, whose abstract sculptures, drawings, and forms in brass greatly informed the orientation of the young American artist. 

The Drawing Center exhibition will be the first in-depth consideration of Richard Pousette-Dart’s drawings from the 1930s, a period when the artist pursued directly-carved sculpture, yet also painted, experimented with photography, and created numerous works on paper. These early drawings explore Pousette-Dart’s concerns about sculpture and working three-dimensionally, and many reference the figure through full-frontal or profile views as they consider space, orientation, and volume. Additionally, numerous studies allude to dance, animal forms, masks, and heads, and many examples offer an accumulation of abstract and geometric forms, particularly for his brasses—small sculptures meant to be “held in the hand.” The exhibition will include approximately eighty works from the 1930s including drawings, notebooks, and brasses. 

Rashid Johnson: Anxious Men

Since distinguishing himself as the youngest artist in Freestyle, the landmark 2001 exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem, Johnson has established himself as one of the preeminent artists of his generation. Invoking such varied themes as the black experience in America, the dialogue between abstraction and figuration, and the relationship between art and personal identity, Johnson has been discussed within the context of contemporary painting, photography, sculpture, video, installation art, and even performance. Now, with the Anxious Men, drawing enters that list. 

Universally accessible and employing common visual tropes such as the monochrome and the grid, Johnson's work is also self-referential making specific allusion to his upbringing in Chicago and the Afro-centric values of his parents. In Rashid Johnson: Anxious Men, the artist creates a site-specific installation in the Drawing Room gallery. The core of the exhibition is a new series of black-soap-and-wax-on-tile portraits that Johnson calls his “anxious men.” Executed by digging into a waxy surface, they enact a kind of drawing through erasure and represent the first time Johnson has worked figuratively outside of photography or film, and on such a small scale. Whereas Johnson’s previous work has taken a more cerebral approach to questions of race and political identity, the drawn portraits confront the viewer with a visceral immediacy. The portraits will be set within a multi-sensory environment that includes wallpaper featuring a photograph of the artist’s father from the year Johnson was born, and an audio sound track comprised of Melvin Van Peebles’s “Love, That’s America,” a song that originally appeared in Peebles’s 1970 film Watermelon Man and that was recently pressed into service by the Occupy Wall Street movement. In this way, the exhibition will create an immersive space that implicates not only the artist but also the viewer in its interrogation of selfhood and identity.

Open Sessions 5

Open Sessions continues with artist-directed group exhibitions. Open Sessions 6 features the work of Amadeo Azar, Daniel Barroca, Youmna Chlala, Lea Cetera, Onyedika Chuke, Alexandra Lerman, Harold Mendez, Marcelo Moscheta, and Ronny Quevedo. Organized by the artists and Nova Benway and Lisa Sigal, Curators of the Open Sessions program.

Amadeo Azar explores the interrelation between the visual languages of modernism with political and social movements in Latin America, and the way those Utopian moments were disrupted as they encountered local circumstances. Daniel Barroca works with memory and history. His projects map forces anchored by images, objects, words, historical figures, and ideas. Lea Cetera produces temporal installations that examine the mediation of technology and the alienation of the human body. Through recent installations that include filmed performances, the artist attempts to create an alienating/disorienting illusory effect. Youmna Chlala investigates architecture and fate. Her work is situated in places or bodies that translate themselves against or through an external world that is constantly trying to name them. Onyedika Chuke has been assembling an archive termed “The Forever Museum”—a collection of objects and images based on Internet-sourced documents that redistribute images and theories pertaining to civilizations, political rebellions, riots, and warfare. Alexandra Lerman proposes clay as a discursive medium. Her ink circulation drawings and "memory negatives" use copyrighted and patented systems to explore the complexities of contemporary body language and refer to the body located within institutional and natural environments. Harold Mendez draws upon ideas of absence and displacement to reference reconstructions of place and identity in the United States and Latin America, with a focus on how the past manifests in the present, and thereby trigger new inquiry. Marcelo Moscheta excavates the memories inscribed in the stone paths left by the ancient civilizations and uses GPS coordinates to draw his displacement over the surface of the planet. Ronny Quevedo traces culture through history, language, and mapping. Using a variety of forms from personal anecdotes to colloquialisms, coats of arms to store signage, games to modules, his work addresses concepts of displacemen

See you at the Hop,

Todd

results.description:
Want to see how the Ionic SDK works?

Bring your laptop to follow along and create a simple iOS or Android app in an hour with Haik Sahakian! 

Ionic is an open-source framework to build mobile apps using the same tools you use to build web pages. It uses Angular JS for its architecture, Apache Cordova to use a phone's features, and web technologies like JavaScript, HTML and CSS.

Haik Sahakian is Director of Algomi's Front-End Development team in New York City. He has created mobile apps and sites for Morgan Stanley and Fidelity Investments. Haik is an Adjunct Professor at Pace University, teaching CS 641 Mobile Web Development, which covers JavaScript-based mobile app development, mobile graphics, and responsive web design.

Ionic:

http://ionicframework.com

Angular JS:

https://angularjs.org

Apache Cordova: 

https://cordova.apache.org
results.name: Create a simple mobile app in an hour, with JavaScript and the Ionic SDK

This is a FREE event, but RSVP is REQUIRED to attend.  We are asking for a $10 deposit to reserve your spot, which will be refunded immediately after event attendance.  You must attend the event in order to receive a refund. 

Join MetroNY AWIS and Women in Science at Columbia (WISC) for a night of networking, featuring a workshop by Faculty of 1000 (F1000). 

F1000 is a company that provides collaborative authoring, reference sharing, literature discovery and annotation powered by a faculty of over 10,000 leading experts in biology and medicine. 

Attendees will get an introduction to Faculty of 1000 and a demo of the new Workspace tool. Complimentary access to Faculty of 1000 will be given to all participants if they don't already have it through their institutions.  For more details, please visit our website.


Pizza, wine and soda will be provided!

Questions? Please email us at <a>[masked]</a> with any questions.


We hope to see you there!

results.description:
This group offers support for men and women who are 50+ and thinking of separating and divorcing or are already in the midst of a divorce or are dealing with post-divorce.  Every phase of life brings different issues and questions and all people do not fit into a one-size-fits-all mold.


If you are considering (or are in the midst of) a divorce after the age of 50, your concerns are different, as are your potential risks and possible mistakes and so here's a group created just for you.   Life has given us a different perspective than when we were younger and you know that no one can be an expert on every topic but you learn to get the information needed when it is required.  This group is here to make that information-gathering process easier and it will also be a comfortable place get all your legal questions answered and meet some other people going through a similar situation at the same time as you.

Some of the issues that will be discussed that may be unique to our phase of life are pensions, retirements, maintenance, social security, the adult children, maybe there are grandchildren and the house.  We hope you will join the next group meeting.

This group is combined with the Separation and Divorce Legal Group to increase the likelihood of group support and we also try to promote it via calendar of events in the community. As this group grows, we will separate the groups -- this way works best for now.

Bring your questions for an even livelier discussion. We look forward to seeing you then.

If this date is not good for you, this group meets on the first and third Thursday of every  month. We also offer a free consultation appointment in our office at a time that is convenient for you -- you can make that appointment whether you attend this group meeting or not.

You can also visit www.lawjaw.com for more info about our law firm.

Meeting is from 6:00pm to 7:30pm.  Please call the office at[masked] if you cannot arrive by 6:30pm.
results.how_to_find_us: Just west of Community Drive
results.name: Join us for the next DIVORCE OVER 50 meeting

With just two weeks before the National Day of Climate Action, the work is kicking into high gear here in NYC. On Wednesday, Oct 14th, our events in NY will add to the more than 100 activities around the country. It will be an exciting day, and we invite you to help us make it real.

We realize this is not a lot of advanced notice, to put it mildly, but 10/14 planning groups hopes you will be able to make it to a city-wide mobilizing meeting this Thursday evening. Here are the details:
WHAT: organizing meeting for NYC 10/14 events as part of the National Day of Climate Action

DATE: This Thursday, Oct. 1st!
TIME: 6 pm to 8 pm
WHERE: Patagonia store in Soho - 72 Greene St., 2nd floor - between Broome and Spring

Closest subways include the #6 to Spring Street, the C or E to Spring, the R to Prince, and the F or D to Broadway/Lafayette.

There is a lot of construction on the block so you’ll need to look for the entrance...
Please help get the word out about this important meeting. This is an open meeting, all are welcome!!

results.description:
Speakers:


Steven Kuyan

Channeling Military Skills to Incubator Startups 

Steven Kuyan is Managing Director of Incubators and Entrepreneurship at the NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering. He co-founded and is responsible for managing two of the three incubators located at Varick Street in Soho and DUMBO in Brooklyn. On campus, Steven develops strategic initiatives to accelerate innovation at the University through programs that catalyze student innovation. 

Kristen Matter is detailing as an assistant to the NYC Engagement Manager.  In this role, she work with innovators, entrepreneurs, and local educators in and around New York  City, providing them with appropriate information and resources offered by the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) and the Department of Commerce.

Ms. Matter is also currently a Primary Patent Examiner in the Pro Se Assistance Program. Before coming to the USPTO, Kristen worked at Nationwide Children’s Hospital in Columbus, Ohio, as a research assistant in the Center for Injury Research and Policy. Ms. Matter began her career at the USPTO in 2006 as a patent examiner and became a primary patent examiner in 2011. In 2008, Kristen moved to NYC to attend Fordham Law School part time while continuing in her role as a patent examiner. Ms. Matter is registered to practice law in Ohio and Washington, DC. Kristen received the Department of Commerce Bronze Medal Award for Superior Federal Service in 2013, and the American Intellectual Property Law Association Examiner Award in 2014. In addition to her J.D. from Fordham Law, Kristen received her Bachelor’s degree in Mechanical Engineering and Master’s degrees in Mechanical Engineering and Biomedical Engineering from The Ohio State University.

Arpan Savla is detailing as an assistant to the NYC Engagement Manager.  In this role, he works with innovators, entrepreneurs, and local educators in and around New York  City, providing them with appropriate information and resources offered by the United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) and the Department of Commerce.

Mr. Savla began his career at the USPTO in 2005 and is currently a Primary Patent Examiner in the Computer Architecture and Software area.  Arpan graduated magna cum laude from Boston University in 2005 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering.

Ryan Letts, Brooklyn SBDC

results.description:
As seen in the CNBC Documentary The Bitcoin Uprising.


Enter “The Nakamoto Circle of All Satoshi Squares” aka the World’s Largest Direct Sellers-to-Buyers Bitcoin Trading Pit! 

Starting at 6:00 p.m. Bitcoin Center NYC welcomes Satoshi Square for a night of spontaneous Bitcoin trading in a LIVE open outcry trading pit. Buy or sell Bitcoins with Satoshi Square and others, or just observe and enjoy a party among fellow Bitcoin enthusiasts. Open bar!

This event is perfect for expert and novice traders as well as exhibitors, vendors, hardware and software developers, educators, students, media, and anyone wanting to be acquainted with the technology. Talk to our experts and get feedback concerning Bitcoin-related startups, as we are an incubator for these. Gaze upon MiningBot and Cash2BTC, two examples of path-breaking Bitcoin hardware the center co-developed. Meet or become a center sponsor and get exposure among the right audience and media!

No matter the focus of your Bitcoin interest or your expertise level, you are welcome. Bring a friend who might have read or heard something about Bitcoin. With our assistance he or she will leave with a better understanding and their first electronic or paper wallet. 

All trading is organic, spontaneous, and occurs directly between sellers and buyers. There are no intermediaries, and no fees as we are neither a trading floor nor a brokerage. Drinks and hospitality are courtesy of Bitcoin Center NYC. 

Details follow. See you there!

results.description:
Updated March 8th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

SPRING/SUMMER (Mar - Aug)

As the city warms up we play four times a week. Our main location is Riverside Park, with Morningside as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)
- Thursdays at 6pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the B or C local to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

+++

OTHER SEASONS...

WINTER (Nov - Feb)

During the colder months we generally play two times a week depending on weather. Our main location is Riverside Park with Morningside as a backup.

There are two days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
- Sundays at 1pm, Riverside Park (108th and West End - Big Soccer Field)
*Tuesdays/Thursdays at 6pm games don't last long due to decreasing sunlight.

FALL (Sep - Oct)

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Morningside Park (110th and Manhattan Ave)
- Sundays at 4pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End)

results.description:
STSANY welcomes NEW MEMBERS, FIRST-TIMERS, Pros, Non-Pros, Semi-Pros and invited GUESTS to our Fall workshop on Thursday, October 1st. 

All workshops benefit members who want to improve their vocal, acting  and instrumental technique and interpretation. They provide a safe, supportive, enjoyable atmosphere which addresses self-confidence, stage fright and other matters important to our members. Workshops are a first step in providing performance and volunteer opportunities.

You may invite up to 2 friends to observe or participate! Come to this and other MEETUP WORKSHOPS and get started pursuing your dreams of learning and performing. You will find a friendly, welcoming atmosphere where you receive expert instruction and encouragement! All workshops begin with group warm-ups.

Meetup Fees: Members: $20; Guests; $15; Observers: $10. Policy: Exact amount in cash at the door.

Please arrive 10 minutes prior to the meetup, if possible, as elevators are busy at that hour.

RSVP Deadline is 10:45 p.m. on Wednesday, September 30 for this meetup. You MUST RSVP on the posting page, even if you have emailed me or spoken to me about attending. If you miss the deadline and would like to attend, please send me an email and include your email address and phone number. I will respond! 

MEETUPS serve several purposes: 

* Learning: You are given instruction in singing and acting technique and interpretation, and you also learn from watching and listening to others. 

* Networking: You are encouraged to exchange information with other members (before, at a break and after the meetup) with whom you feel an affinity, personally and/or performance-wise, and to possibly collaborate with them on  STSANY projects or outside the meetup;

* Volunteering: Please volunteer to be an assistant organizer (talk to me about your special talents!), and to help out at our various events;

* Social: Enjoy meeting and getting to know others either before, during a break, or after meetup is over.

IMPORTANT! Although I ALWAYS send updates, if necessary, be sure to keep checking the postings for meetups and your emails about the day and time of each meetup. Weather conditions, illness and unforeseen events can cause cancellations. 

For all meetup workshops: (Please read, carefully!)

 Singers: Bring 2 contrasting songs of any style (entire sheet music) - 2 copies, please. If you don't have written songs, let me know and I can provide some at the meetup.

NOTE! If you don't wish to sing solo, please join us in our group numbers. Getting started is the important thing.  The shyness will subside, little by little.

Actors: Bring 2 contrasting monologues, poems or recitations - 2 copies, please.

Instrumentalists: Be prepared to play one or two contrasting pieces of any style.

YOU ARE ENCOURAGED TO RECORD the meetups for continued learning and inspiration!

NOTE: PRIVATE LESSONS are offered from 11:00 a.m to 8:00 p.m., by appointment, on weekdays/nights, and on Saturdays (sometimes Sundays) from 10:00 a.m.-1:00 p.m.  Cost: $65 for 45 minutes. Some further discounts may be available. Read your emails. RSVP on each posting, separately, for lessons and kindly adhere to all the details.

NOTE: TO read about STSANY's GOALS and reviews, click on pages: http://www.meetup.com/SOMETHING-TO-SING-ABOUT-IN-NEW-YORK/about/

To see and hear members perform, please VISIT and SUBSCRIBE TO our youtube channel by clicking on this link: https://www.youtube.com/user/AlmaMusica/videos?view_as=public

I look forward to seeing and working with you on Thursday, October 1 and beyond! Workshops are usually scheduled once or twice a month.

Be inspired and live your DREAMS! Carpe diem!

All the best,

Anna Bartos

www.annabartos.com

Founder-Director, STSANY since 2010

Founder-Director, Flor y Canto Chamber Ensemble since 1998

NYU Vocal Faculty from[masked] 

REVIEWS by STSANY members, fellow performers and audience members: 

Anna Bartos is not only a superb singing teacher (she knows her music), she is an equally excellent coach, which is a rarity among singing teachers. She is also capable of imparting manyhelpful nuggets of information about the process of singing and performing that one doesn't usually receive from one's teacher. I found her instruction of enormous value.___. P. Vincent, NYC actor, playwright and STSANY showcase performer.

It was a wonderful session w/a warm, knowledgeable & insightful instructor & in great company!____Allyson, Member, STSANY

Great session; good, helpful feedback; supportive.____Barbara, Member, STSANY

“ Fortunately for me I had the pleasure of Anna helping me with my singing technique which is something that I have always to do. I am looking forward to more meetups and meeting new people. You should all attend this meetup whether you are experienced or a beginner (like me). You will be able to discover something so unique and wonderful about yourself with this group. I can guarantee it! ”______Chels, Members, STSANY

An excellent meetup! Anna knows her stuff and helped me improve my performances; the other members/performers are talented and friendly and fun."____Glen, Member, STSANY

The MUSICALE was a wonderfully diverse program in an intimate setting. I found the preliminary workshops extremely helpful in putting a role I'd worked on (for longer than I'd like to say) into a historical, musical, and linguistic framework. I am eager to do more! Anna Bartos is knowledgeable about a broad range of musical styles and genres, acting and character development as well as singing. I would definitely like to perform in this type of event again. For me, once a season would be good (3-4 times a year)."____Rebecca, Member of STSANY (Musicale on 1/19/14)

Amazing event. Thank you, Anna for holding the musicale. I am also glad to meet new singers.___Saadat, Member of STSANY

What a delightful surprise! One often doesn't know what to expect of a showcase! Congratulations to Anna, a real pro, and an impressive mentor to a diverse array of talent. The 'meet-up' seems to be a real resource for both the performers and those of us in the audience.  Keep up the good work!____Mary Jay, Seasoned Senior Performer

It was a privilege to work with Anna Bartos on this 9/11 memorial concert. All of the performers were of high caliber and the audience rewarded our efforts with heartfelt applause. The program, with its mixture of styles and its emphasis on Americana, was just perfect for the anniversary date. I had a great time yesterday. It was a meaningful and well-organized concert.___ Moshe Knoll, Classical pianist.

Thank you so much for inviting us to perform on this wonderful 9/11 concert.___Rosa Hyewon, Classical Guitarist

Would you like to -

• Become a more confident public speaker?

•Feel more at-ease during business meetings and social occasions?

•Make new friends, in a supportive and encouraging environment?

The friendly people at Pride Toastmasters would love to help you improve your public speaking skills, as you boost your leadership and self confidence skills! We focus on making our guests very welcome. We meet every Thursday from 6:15 p.m. until 7:25 at the LGBT Center, 208 W 13th St, New York, NY 10011. If you arrive early, expect to be warmly greeted and given an overview of what to expect during the fun, informative and engaging meeting! 

By the way, there’s nothing for you to prepare in advance of our meeting, no fee to pay as our guest and no pressure to join.  Please do visit and sample this exciting option for personal and professional growth!

An average of 20 members and guests attend each Pride Toastmasters meeting. Since most aren't members of Meetup, the attendance figures shown here are always much lower.

Please visit our web site at http://www.PrideToastmasters.com

results.description:
Graybar Toastmasters is open to all who wish to improve their public speaking and leadership skills. In addition, this is a great way to network with a dynamic and diverse group of professionals.

Founded in 1954, we are one of the oldest Toastmasters clubs in New York City. We are a friendly club with members dedicated to helping each other become better speakers.

We meet from 6:15pm to 8:15pm on the 1st and 3rd Thursdays of each month in the same location. 

Our meetings are structured to allow everbody participate, practice and learn.

In our meetings the members of the club take different roles that allow them to practice and improve their public speaking and leadership skills by completing different projects.

The different roles include giving prepared presentations, chairing the meeting, improvising a short speech, telling a joke, giving feedback to speakers, evaluating the whole meeting, among others, all in a very friendly and supportive environment.

People who RSVP this meetup attend as guests. They introduce themselves at the beginning of the meeting and give feedback at the end, and some of them may participate in an improv exercise, this is an opportunity for you to check out the club coming to one or a couple of meetings, and decide if you want to join as an active member. 

To learn more about Toastmasters International please visit http://www.toastmasters.org/

See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: 28 East 35th Street, between Park and Madison in New York City. To enter, please press buzzer #2 outside the red door for the Gallery/Lounge on the 1st Floor. PLEASE attend the meeting only if you RSVP since the space available is limited.

results.description:
Have you ever wondered how to get started with Shapeways and 3D printing? Are you curious about the materials we print and want to experience the factory first hand? 

"Shapeways 101" is a crash course that will equip you with the essential information on how to navigate and utilize the site to begin 3D printing. You will be provided a 3D model by Shapeways to upload, customize and place your order.

After the tutorial, the Shapeways team will tour you through our “Factory of the Future” to demonstrate how your model is printed and shipped out to you.

The tools and information provided on Shapeways offer amazing capabilities and have essential information for a successful print. This tutorial is perfect for beginners who are looking to jump into 3d printing. 

*The fee for this tutorial will be credited back to your Shapeways account.


***REQUIRED: Please bring a laptop to this event, as it is a learning tutorial!
results.name: Getting Started with Shapeways & Factory Tour

results.description:
We hear from moms all the time, “I just want to avoid a cesarean.” But we all know that just stating it doesn’t mean it won’t happen. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the Society for Maternal Fetal Medicine (SMFM) are similarly concerned about the high rate of cesareans nationally. Last year these organizations teamed up to release new guidelines for doctors in the hopes of lowering the number of first cesareans in the U.S.

Join CiC and facilitator Mary Esther Malloy on October 1st for this first ever presentation of “Preventing First Cesareans”. Familiarize yourself with the new ACOG/SMFM guidelines and learn about steps you can take to minimize the likelihood of an unnecessary cesarean. Mother-Friendly care providers will be on hand to answer your questions as you consider what is best for you. Registration details: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/preventing-first-cesareans-tickets-17779622329 Cesarean section is a life-saving surgery which, when used appropriately, can be the safest course of action. It is not without risk however. Choices in Childbirth wants consumers to be in on the game so that you can strategize ways to avoid an unnecessary primary cesarean section.
results.name: All About Birth: Preventing First Cesareans

group.name: New York Pregnant and Expecting Meetup

A Database Month event: http://www.DBMonth.com/database/sql-nosql

Jeffrey M. Birnbaum, Founder & CEO, 60East Technologies

This session is geared towards people who are interested in staying relevant in the innovative and fast-paced world of real time data challenges. 

In this session we will share insights into how to solve a range of big data and grid-like problems utilizing the world's first high performance computing queue.

Does your projects need fast pub-sub messaging? SQL data retrieval? NoSQL object storage? Low-latency data aggregation? Data queuing, querying and filtering? To build complex distributed applications in the real world, you need all of these, and you need them all to work together with no wasted overhead or latency.

Do not miss this opportunity to see our Wall Street technology pioneer, Jeffrey M. Birnbaum, describe practical innovations in high-performance computing that minimize the burden and complexity of databases systems while providing massive-scalability that can keep up as microchips, networks and storage technologies improve.

Jeffrey M. Birnbaum, Founder & CEO, 60East Technologies

Jeffrey is a seasoned executive and software developer with over 25 years of experience. Named one of the top 10 CIOs on Wall Street by Securities Technology Monitor, Jeffrey has worked at the largest Wall Street firms in the world, where he created compute and application programming infrastructures used to build high-performance, real-time electronic trading and risk systems.

In 2006, Jeffrey set out to create the Advanced Message Processing System specifically designed to lower the burden of developing high-performance end-user applications by combining modern parallel programming techniques with advances in multicore systems, low latency networking and storage hardware. Jeffrey holds a BS in Electrical Computer Engineering from University of California Santa Barbara. He began his career as a systems engineer in the Aerospace industry.

results.description:
In addition to our semi-annual conferences, throughout the year ONUG will conduct smaller user-centered meetings across the country focused on driving open software defined cloud infrastructure. The informal meetups will provide year round opportunities for the existing ONUG Community to engage with new IT leaders and continue the discussion on topics introduced at the semi-annual conferences.

ONUG Board and community members will lead a lively discussion on linking network infrastructure into cloud orchestration tools. One of the key goals of software defined infrastructure is to automate the initial configuration and ongoing management of network equipment. Some are automating the operations of Top of Rack switches with a Mesosphere network plug-in, which looks promising and perhaps points to a viable direction. How will OpenStack, Docker, VCenter, Puppet, Chef, Ansible as well as vendor specific network orchestration emerge. We’ll discuss best practices and industry directions at this ONUG Meetup.  

30 minute welcome & networking – 6:30-7:00

1 hour panel and discussion (Q&A) – 7:00-8:00

30 minutes follow-up & networking – 8:00-8:30

Food and beverage will be provided. 

Parking:


1. Sound Parking: 6 E 17th Street www.championparking.com

2. Icon Parking: 16 W 16th Street www.iconparkingsystems.com

3. Icon Parking: 65 W 15th Street www.iconparkingsystems.com


About ONUG:

ONUG’s mission is to guide and accelerate the adoption of open software defined cloud infrastructure solutions that meet IT end user requirements as defined through use cases, proof of concepts, and deployments to ensure user needs are met. Throughout the year, ONUG meetups will be attended by members of the ONUG Board, which is comprised of representatives from Bank of America, BNY Mellon, Cigna, Citigroup, Credit Suisse, FedEx, Fidelity Investments, Gap, Inc., Intuit, JPMorgan Chase, the Lippis Report, Morgan Stanley, Pfizer, UBS, and Yahoo.  

For more information on ONUG, visit www.opennetworkingusergroup.com

About Work-Bench:

Work-Bench is an enterprise technology venture fund in New York City. Work-Bench is building a home for our #nextgenterprise community of enterprise startups, technologists,corporations and more in New York City.

You will have the opportunity to:

*Network with a group of successful Real Estate Investors.

*Learn how rental properties are one of the best tax saving strategies out there.

*Learn how to be your own boss.

*Find out how you can earn while you learn Real Estate

Investing.

*Learn how to build massive wealth with strategies such as Fix

and Flips and passive wealth with rental properties.

*And so much more.

Each meeting is different as we will show you different deals we've completed recently. We will also show you how you can be included in the deals we have going forward. 

Some of our members invest part time for residual income while others have been able to FIRE THEIR BOSS to invest full time. If you are interested in learning how to make consistent $30,000 or more per deal please RSVP. We have a wide network of Real Estate Investors local to the NY Metro Area that will show you how.

results.description:
Dive deeper, Soar higher: MADlib + HAWQ for advanced SQL machine learning on Hadoop with Pivotal and Hortonworks speakers

The growing Apache ecosystem just got bigger and better -- now with the ability to crunch vast volumes of data using fully ANSI-compliant SQL and at-scale machine learning algorithms.

Apache HAWQ has been years in the making and derives its heritage from Greenplum Database and PostgreSQL. HAWQ enables developers, analysts, data scientists and engineers to run advanced SQL queries, transforming data sets of extreme size, visualizing data with standard tools, and seamlessly running R and Python in a highly-distributed fashion all in the same environment. Invoke powerful machine learning and advanced statistical functions using Apache MADlib, and build models on billions of rows of data.

Speakers from Pivotal and Hortonworks will discuss the following:

•  Introduction to Apache HAWQ & Apache MADlib

•  All about the Open Data Platform initiative

•  Data science in the Hadoop ecosystem

•  Live, end-to-end data science demo using Apache HAWQ, Apache MADLib, and Hortonworks Data Platform

Speakers:
Frank McQuillan is Director of Product Management at Pivotal, focusing on analytics and machine learning. Prior to Pivotal, Frank worked on projects in the areas of on-line advertising technology, robotics, drones and real-time flight simulation.

Sarah Aerni is a Principal Data Scientist at Pivotal leading the San Francisco practice. She executes projects with customers from pharmaceutical companies and healthcare providers to financial institutions. Before Pivotal, Sarah obtained her PhD from Stanford University in Biomedical Informatics, performing research at the interface of biomedicine and machine learning. She also co-founded a company offering expert services in informatics to both academia and industry.

Tim Hall is Vice President of Product Management at Hortonworks. Prior to joining Hortonworks, he was vice president of product management at Oracle,  responsible for leading Oracle’s outbound product management team covering the Business Process Management Suite, SOA Suite offerings including Oracle Event Processing, and the Data Integration Suite. Previously, Tim held management level positions at HP, Talking Blocks, and Xpedior. Tim holds a Bachelor of Arts degree from Claremont McKenna College in Science and Management with a concentration in Physics. Follow Tim on Twitter: @TimHallHWX.


[We are hiring locally and for many other locations in the US!! Come talk to us, We have open positions for Data Engineering and Data Science roles at Associate and Senior levels.]
results.name: Apache MADlib + Apache HAWQ for advanced SQL machine learning on Hadoop

This session is geared towards people who are interested in staying relevant in the innovative and fast-paced world of real time data challenges. 

In this session we will share insights into how to solve a range of big data and grid-like problems utilizing the world's first high performance computing queue.

Does your projects need fast pub-sub messaging? SQL data retrieval? NoSQL object storage? Low-latency data aggregation? Data queuing, querying and filtering? To build complex distributed applications in the real world, you need all of these, and you need them all to work together with no wasted overhead or latency.

Do not miss this opportunity to see our Wall Street technology pioneer, Jeffrey M. Birnbaum, describe practical innovations in high-performance computing that minimize the burden and complexity of databases systems while providing massive-scalability that can keep up as microchips, networks and storage technologies improve.

Jeffrey M. Birnbaum, Founder & CEO, 60East Technologies

Jeffrey is a seasoned executive and software developer with over 25 years of experience. Named one of the top 10 CIOs on Wall Street by Securities Technology Monitor, Jeffrey has worked at the largest Wall Street firms in the world, where he created compute and application programming infrastructures used to build high-performance, real-time electronic trading and risk systems.

In 2006, Jeffrey set out to create the Advanced Message Processing System specifically designed to lower the burden of developing high-performance end-user applications by combining modern parallel programming techniques with advances in multicore systems, low latency networking and storage hardware. Jeffrey holds a BS in Electrical Computer Engineering from University of California Santa Barbara. He began his career as a systems engineer in the Aerospace industry.

FREE DESIGNER T-SHIRTS! See photo below!

The T-shirt designer said "People need to come to DBMonth to discover the technology that inspired such badass artwork."

RSVP now at http://www.NYCSQL.com/events/225514090/

Swag giveaway + food/drinks at 6:30pm
Power-Networking at 6:35pm 
Presentation starts at 6:40pm

(saving child's life is very easy!)

results.description:
Curious about code? Struggling to learn the intricacies of web development on your own? Want to learn face-to-face with others in a welcoming community?

Join us and discover the language that makes the Web interactive: JavaScript. Pressing space on your favorite video streaming site to pause the video? JavaScript. Clicking “Compose” in your Web-based email client and a new message box pops up on the screen? JavaScript.

In this workshop, we will walk you through the basics of the JavaScript language and how to use it to communicate with the HTML/CSS on a web page. We’ll cover:

* All the tools you need to get up, running and coding with JavaScript

* Basic programming concepts like variables, loops, functions, strings, arrays and objects

* How to write these things in JavaScript

* Interacting with the HTML and CSS of a webpage using JavaScript

*Available resources if you’d like to continue learning

This event is open to adult (18+) beginners and is an introduction to concepts covered more deeply in the immersive program. Please bring your own laptop (Mac, PC or Chromebook). Light snacks will be provided.

Prerequisite: A basic understanding of HTML/CSS and JavaScript (e.g. topics covered in Codecademy’s HTML & CSS and JavaScript tracks).

Build your programming knowledge independently or collectively in our workshop series:
</a><a href="http://www.meetup.com/DBC-NYC/events/225240312/?action=edit">HTML/CSS for Beginners - evening workshop [9/29 from 6:30-9pm] 
Javascript for Beginners - evening workshop [10/1 from 6:30-9:30pm] 
Ruby for Beginners - evening workshop [10/6 from 6:30-9:30pm] 
Full Stack Development - day long weekend workshop [10/10 from 10am-6pm]<a href="http://www.meetup.com/DBC-NYC/events/224450141"></a>

results.description:
Dear friends, 

This time we will host Karthik Ramasamy, engineering manager and technical lead for Real Time Analytics at Twitter.

Abstract:

Storm has long served as the main platform for real-time analytics at Twitter. However, as the scale of data being processed in real- time at Twitter has increased, along with an increase in the diversity and the number of use cases, many limitations of Storm have become apparent. We need a system that scales better, has better debug-ability, has better performance, and is easier to manage – all while working in a shared cluster infrastructure. We considered various alternatives to meet these needs, and in the end concluded that we needed to build a new real-time stream data processing system. This talk will present the design and implementation of the new system, called Heron. Heron is now the de facto stream data processing engine inside Twitter, and we share our experiences from running Heron in production.

Speaker Bio

Karthik is the engineering manager and technical lead for Real Time Analytics at Twitter. He has two decades of experience working in parallel databases, big data infrastructure and networking. He cofounded Locomatix, a company that specializes in real time streaming processing on Hadoop and Cassandra using SQL that was acquired by Twitter. Before Locomatix, he had a brief stint with Greenplum where he worked on parallel query scheduling. Greenplum was eventually acquired by EMC for more than $300M. Prior to Greenplum, Karthik was at Juniper Networks where he designed and delivered platforms, protocols, databases and high availability solutions for network routers that are widely deployed in the Internet. Before joining Juniper at University of Wisconsin, he worked extensively in parallel database systems, query processing, scale out technologies, storage engine and online analytical systems. Several of these research were spun as a company later acquired by Teradata.

He is the author of several publications, patents and one of the best selling book "Network Routing: Algorithms, Protocols and Architectures." He has a Ph.D. in Computer Science from UW Madison with a focus on databases.


Agenda:

6 :30 pm:  Guest arrival & networking.

7: 00 pm:  Twitter Heron: Stream Processing at Scale

8.30pm:  event ends.

Strata + Hadoop World, happening September 29 - October 1, 2015 in New York,  is where cutting-edge science and new business fundamentals intersect. It's a deep-immersion event where data scientists, analysts, and executives explore the latest in emerging techniques and technologies by dissecting case studies, developing new skills through in-depth tutorials, and sharing best practices. 

Register before it's gone using our group discount code and link below. 

Save 20% on any pass with discount code UGNYCSUG20. 

Check out the impressive agenda and speaker lineup. Strata conference is the most interesting Big Data event in New York.

Kristina :)

This is a FREE yoga class that meets from 6:30 to 8:00 pm, instructed by Chia-Ti Chiu, one of the organizers of this Meetup group.

*** For this class, Oct 1, Calia Marshall will sub.  Chia-Ti will resume classes on Oct 8 ***

It is an OPEN LEVEL HATHA FLOW class, appropriate for beginners to advanced students.  There are many variations given to accommodate the different levels of yoga experience.


** You will need to bring your own mat.  There are no yoga mats for rent or use. You can buy yoga mats inexpensively at Marshalls, Filene's Basement, Modells, TJ Maxx, and Target. Many yoga studios also carry a wide range of mats for sale.

IF YOU COME FOR THE FIRST TIME: PLEASE FILL OUT THE REGISTRATION FORM AT THE FRONT DESK. RSVPing on Meetup does not count as Beacon registration.  Your participation and registration helps keep the numbers needed for this program to stay free!


FOR EVERYONE: PLEASE SIGN IN AT THE FRONT DESK CLEARLY AND LEGIBLY

DIRECTIONS:The Beacon Center is located in PS 198. It is an elementary school that takes up the whole block; entrance is on 3rd Ave. The exact address is: 1700 Third Avenue, between 95 & 96 St.

BY SUBWAY: 6 train to 96 St. Walk 1 block East on 96 St to Third Ave. Make a right onto Third Ave.

BY BUS: Third Ave Bus - M101, 102, 103 to 96 St.

Madison Ave Bus - M1, M2,M3, or M4 To 96 St.


ANY QUESTIONS? Contact Chia-Ti through Meetup or through her website: www.onelovewellness.com

results.description:
I'm loving the momentum of this group and witnessing how folks are improving their language skills and making friends. To me, it makes all of this worth doing!

So let's get ready for another great meetup! 

As always, first introduce yourself in the language you are studying. Then introduce yourself in your native language. 

Following that, we will dedicate 30 minutes towards helping those learning English, then 30 minutes of Chinese. 

Then we mingle again until its time to go. 

We are usually done by 8:30 but those that want to stick around or continue hanging out after the meetup (bubble tea, karaoke, etc) are more than welcome to do so!

Thanks again for your support thus far and let's have many more great meetups! 非常感谢大家的支持！

results.description:
New York Tarot Tarotology is a class devoted to the study of the pictorial language of the Tarot. Have you ever wondered "What do the cards mean?" Or, "Why does every book you've looked at say the cards mean something else?" This class will answer both those questions. 

The on-going classes, will feature Tarot Symbolism, the Esoteric Titles assigned to each card in the Tarot as well as what each title means, Astrology and the Tarot, Qabalah and the Tarot, which includes a study of the Tree of Life,  Alchemy and the Tarot, as well as the History of the Tarot. 

All levels are welcome, even if this is your very first class.

Bella Napoli has good Italian food. You can order anything from salad, to pizza, to sandwiches to a complete dinner. 

There will be a Meet-Up sign on the table.

Although it says that we will start at 7:00 PM, that time is just for people who would like to have a little something to eat and socialize in order to unwind from their day, before the class begins. The actual class starts begins at around 8:00 PM and can run a little over to enable people to have their questions answered. I will arrive at 7:00 PM. 

Payment can be made in class.

results.description:
Sold out! No new RSVPs.


Machu Picchu is a 15th-century Inca site located on a ridge between the Huayna Picchu and Machu Picchu mountains in Peru. It sits 7,970 feet (2,430 meters) above sea level on the eastern slope of the Andes and overlooks the Urubamba River hundreds of feet below. The site’s excellent preservation, the quality of its architecture, and the breathtaking mountain vista it occupies has made Machu Picchu one of the most famous archaeological sites in the world today.

I have been wanting to go here for some time and have stumbled upon a great rate for an escorted tour including air! Though the trip is quick (5 days/3 nights), it includes the following:


• International roundtrip airfare from the JFK to Cuzco

• Intra-country flights and all airport transfers

• English-speaking tour guide throughout

• Two nights in colonial Cusco, a UNESCO World Heritage Site

• One night in the serene Urubamba Sacred Valley

• All transportation, including a train ride to Machu Picchu

• Four meals: daily breakfast; one dinner


COST: The basic trip which includes all of the above is $1279

• Price is for double occupancy (Travel agency can pair you up with another)


• Tours noted as OPTIONAL are not include in base price

TO BOOK: You can lock in the rate and reservation with only a $200 deposit. The remaining amount can be paid by August 10, 2015. Call Justin at Gate 1 Travel at[masked] ext. 1380. to book your trip. Make sure you tell him you are traveling with me!

Itinerary: This 5 day “on-the-go” program features the highlights of Peru in an active itinerary which includes several walking tours as well as some early starts and long days.

DAY 1, Thursday - Depart for Peru
Depart for Peru. Your flight includes meals, drinks, and in-flight entertainment for your journey

DAY 2, Friday - Arrive in Lima and Fly to Cuzco
Early this morning arrive in Lima and connect to your flight to Cuzco with help from a Gate 1 representative. Upon your arrival in Cuzco, meet your Tour Manager and enjoy a scenic drive to your hotel in the Sacred Valley. The balance of the day is at leisure. This evening, enjoy an orientation meeting with your Tour Manager, followed by a Welcome Dinner
Optional: Pisac Village & Market (PM)
Overnight: Urubamba Sacred Valley
Meals: Dinner

DAY 3, Saturday - Full Day Machu Picchu
Early this morning, transfer to the Sacred Valley's Ollanta Station and board the Inca Rail train for Machu Picchu, a UNESCO World Heritage Site virtually unknown to the western world until Hiram Bingham's "re" discovery in 1911. Spend the afternoon viewing the ancient citadel before boarding the train for your return to the Sacred Valley's Ollanta Station in the evening. Upon arrival, transfer to your hotel in Cuzco
Overnight: Cuzco
Meals: Breakfast

DAY 4, Sunday - Full Day in Cuzco
Spend today at leisure in "The Imperial City". Take time to sightsee or shop independently. Cuzco is declared the Historical Capital by the Constitution of Peru and hosts nearly 1 million visitors every year. Visit some of the numerous Inca monuments or join one of the many fascinating optional tours available today in Cuzco
Optional: Half Day Cuzco Behind the Scenes (AM)
Optional: Half Day Highlights of Cuzco (PM)
Optional: Highlights of Cuzco & Cuzco Behind the Scenes Combo Package
Optional: Home Hosted Dinner in Cuzco (PM)
Overnight: Cuzco
Meals: Breakfast

DAY 5, Monday - Full Day in Cuzco, Fly to Lima
Enjoy the day at leisure or join the optional morning Half Day Ancient Cuzco Ruins tour. Time permitting, meet children at a local school before transferring to the Cuzco airport for your connecting flight to Lima
Optional: Half Day Ancient Cuzco Ruins (AM)
Meals: Breakfast

DAY 6, Tuesday - Arrive in USA
results.name: Machu Picchu Express (Land & Air)

October again, and time once more for our Twisted Stitchers semiannual Yarn Swap.  Time to take a stash dive and pull out the skeins and balls and hanks that you no longer want or need.  The yarn leftover from the big project you finished?  Bring it to Yarn Swap!  Those skeins of yarn in the color that's not quite right for you (or for anyone you'd crochet for)?  Bring them to the Yarn Swap!  Those balls of yarn that make you wonder "Did I ever like this?"  Bring them to the Yarn Swap!

results.description:
CHECK IT OUT FOR ONLY $5 BUCKS! 


Welcome To The Writer’s Room 
 This is the only class of its kind—run like a real writer’s room on a 30 minute TV comedy series, taught by a professional showrunner with over 25 years of industry experience—and featuring the work of 12 talented student writers. You’ll not only learn how to write a half hour spec episode or pilot that can open the door to a job in Hollywood, you’ll actually write one for the show of your choice, and collaborate on the development of a script for a different show each week, just like they do in the big leagues.

What You’ll Learn
You’ll learn the elements of a successful half-hour comedy series, and how to write a pilot or spec episode that shows off your ability to create what every network, studio, and series producer is looking for: a professional grade script plays within the structure of the series for which you want to write, while showing off your unique talent as a writer. You’ll not only have real world experience of working in a TV writer’s room, you’ll also connect with a community of writers you can depend on, and the knowledge you need to write a professional grade pilot you can use to pursue a career in Hollywood. A Teacher You Can Trust With more than 25 years of Hollywood experience, Jerome has been a showrunner, writer, and producer on some of the most successful half-hour series in history, including “The Jeffersons,” “The Golden Girls,” “Frasier,” “The Nanny,” and “Married…with Children.” Now, he brings a lifetime of experience directly to you as your teacher, showrunner, mentor and coach.

Learn more.

NORMAL COST: $899

MEETUP MEMBERS: Check out the first day of this  10-week workshop for only $5 bucks with no obligation!

Class Size is Strictly Limited To 12 Students To Allow All Students The Opportunity to Workshop And Receive Feedback On Their Writing. 

You MUST RSVP to attend this event.

You'll LOVE this workshop or your money back!

And who cultivated whom, humans of wheat? Join us even if you haven’t finished reading.

results.description:
The October comic book club poll winner was Locke & Key Volume 1: Welcome to Lovecraft by Joe Hill!   (good thing it's close to Halloween!)


Bio: Novelist Hill, author of Heart-Shaped Box, crafts a gripping account of the shattered Locke family's attempt to rebuild after the father/husband is murdered by a deranged high school student and the family subsequently moving in with the deceased father's brother at the family homestead in Maine. But as anyone who has read horror fiction in the past 70-odd years will tell you, it's a bad idea to try to leave behind the gruesome goings-on in your life by moving to an island named Lovecraft. What begins as a study in coping with grief soon veers into creepy territory as the youngest Locke discovers a doorway with decidedly spectral qualities, along with a well that houses someone or something that desperately wants out and will use any means available to gain freedom, including summoning the teenage murderer who set events in motion in the first place. To say more would give away many of the surprises the creative team provides, but this first of hopefully several volumes delivers on all counts, boasting a solid story bolstered by exceptional work from Chilean artist Rodriguez (Clive Barker's The Great and Secret Show) that resembles a fusion of Rick Geary and Cully Hamner with just a dash of Frank Quitely.

Purchase:
Amazon
Barnes & Noble
Comixology

or your local comic book store!

eta:  WE HAVE MOVED BACK INDOORS TO THE ATRIUM!
results.name: October Comic Book Club - Locke & Key Vol 1:  Welcome to Lovecraft

results.description:
Dear Friends,

You are cordially invited to attend the next meeting of our shamanic healing circle. Carolina and I have been co - facilitating this bi - weekly circle since the Spring of 2014, averaging 15 - 20 participants. Thanks to all who've attended! Your participation in healing, friendship, and community continues to make our gatherings a big success! The shamanic path is one of living in harmony with nature, honoring and serving all beings, and helping others to do the same. In these circles we'll help everyone get in touch with their own inner shaman by teaching and practicing the principles and techniques of many ancient traditions.

Carolina is on vacation this week so I'll lead the circle alone this time. She'll be back for the next circle. I'll perform a group soul retrieval in this circle. Soul retrieval is a basic shamanic technique which is practiced with many different techniques various traditions. Will we use benevolent magic prayer, meditation, writing of intentions and shamanic drumming in this circle to welcome lost aspects of our souls back into our lives.

In these circles we provide shamanic limpieza (cleansing of the body and energy field with green leafed branches, rum spray and rattling), and drumming for journeying. Please feel free to bring your drum, rattle, crystals and power objects for the altar and snacks for the spirit offering basket.

Carolina Encalada

Artist/Teacher/Shamanic Healing Practitioner - Carolina Encalada is a NYC visual multi - media artist and founder of The Healing Arts Circle, a program that allows children and adults of all ages to connect with their higher self through the creation of art. Carolina's most natural and powerful spiritual tool lies in Shamanism, a knowledge she has mostly acquired from her Ecuadorian roots. Her work, both spiritual and creatively with the use of Shamanic teachings is done with the intention to empower others. She quotes, "I believe everyone has Shaman in them and given the proper guidance and spiritual community support, we can all tap into our gifts and share our medicine." She is Grateful for her shamanic training and studies with Shamanic Practitioner- Itzhak Beery, Elder Vernon Foster, Shamanic Practitioner- Alberto Villoldo, and Shamanic teacher/ Practitioner- Sandra Ingerman.

Reiki certified Level 2 with Reiki Master- Geordie Numata, Attuned by Reconnective Healer/ Reiki Master Peter Goldbeck


Connect with Carolina on Facebook


Geordie Numata

Geordie's shamanic training goes back to his youth, starting with the books of Carlos Castaneda, Shaman's Drum magazine and his many journeys with the sacred plant medicines. He later studied with Barbara Hand Clow (Cherokee / Mayan), Wanagi Wi (Lakota) Ipupiara (Amazonian), Tata Pedro Cruz and Tata Chus Ixim Toj (Mayan) and Roman Hanis (Amazonian). He is a well know NYC healer, teacher, astrologer and ceremonial leader, creator of the Angelic Liquid Light Healing modality, co - founder of The Free Clinic For Recovery and Founder of the Clarion Wellness Community Clinic. He also works part - time leading a team of Reiki and ear acupuncture practitioners at the Lower East Side Harm Reduction Center. His website is http://www.deerspiritreiki.com/

Love & Gratitude,
Geordie & Carolina
results.name: Shamanic Healing Soul Retrieval Circle w/ Geordie

results.description:
TiE NY ANGELS APPLICATION DEADLINES


TiE NY Angels is accepting applications for it's upcoming pitch nights in Oct, Nov and Dec!

Please note we have moved our application process to Gust.  

To submit an application to TiE Angels please visit: https://gust.com/organizations/tie-new-york/public_profile

TiE Angels NY has invested in 4 companies in 2014:  

FitBark  is the world’s tiniest wireless activity tracker for man’s best friend. It collects physical activity and rest levels 24/7, providing you insight into your dog’s behavior and activity trends;

Librify  - an online eBook subscription for social reading; RECENTLY ACQUIRED BY SCRIBD.

American Prison Data Systems (APDS)– creating paperless jail cells and delivering technology that makes prisons safer, cheaper and more efficient.

Socure - combines a patent-pending artificial intelligence system, proprietary machine learning algorithms and social behavior pattern analysis to detect if an ID is authentic, a fraudster or a bot

Zakipoint Health  delivering healthcare cost transparency and effectiveness of spend to self-insured employers, whose healthcare costs have continued to rise to reach $620 bn. Move towards value based healthcare is bringing new opportunities for employers. ZPH helps them see clearly, take action and save money

Minimum Requirements:

• At least two full-time founders

• Prototype developed with customer interaction

• In-house technical talent required for technology companies

• Early stage (pre Series A)

Strong Preferences:

• TiE Annual Members and Charter Members (Join Today)

• Referral from TiE Angels member or TiE Charter Member

• Located in Tri-State Area

• Lead investor including pre-existing commitments for 20% of current round

The mission of TiE Angels NY is to bring investment opportunities from the vast TiE network to the TiE members in New York and bring NY deals to the other chapters of TiE. TiE Angels have done 35+ angel deals for over $13M across the country. Members of TiE Angels have access to unique deal flow sourced from our 55 chapters across the globe, including from our very active Silicon Valley, Boston, Oregon, Seattle, London, Atlanta and India chapters. Companies supported by TiE Angels can leverage our global network of 2,500 charter members and 8,500 members around the world for mentoring, industry expertise and connections.

results.description:
Join us for 2 hour workshop that will help you get started and involved in the open source community! We would love to encourage more of our members to become open source committers and contributors; come find out more information on how to get involved.

About the Workshop

Some of the things we'll cover:

• What is open source? What is the open source "philosophy?" Open source licenses and licensing (what are they and what do they mean).

• Overview of tools project built as open source - you're probably already using or have heard of at least one.

• Brief overview of Git / Github, and other tools used to make open source stuff. PREREQUISITE: you should have an active GitHub account. 

• 5 ways that you can participate in an open source project right now 

Joining a project: Know enough about open source, have a GitHub account and ready to get started contributing to a project? In a separate area from the workshop, others who are already working on open source projects will be there to share information on the projects and help get you involved.  Participants will leave with clear goals and next steps for their work in open source.


All Girl Develop It events follow a Code of Conduct.

Light snacks will be provided for the event. 

About the Instructor

Courteney Ervin is an Events Platform Engineer at CodeMontage. The confluence of open source and social good were the seed of her tech career, and she is thrilled to be writing code at the junction of such important movements. As a self-taught developer, Ervin is also firmly committed to fostering a more diverse tech industry through accessible educational opportunities and supports this commitment with her work on the CodeLift Project, an organization that teaches HTML & CSS to women of color.

Previously, Ervin taught over 100 students as a founding teacher of Dev Bootcamp’s NYC campus and has led events and tech projects at a variety of nonprofits.
results.name: Open Source Contributor Workshop

results.description:
Our next Kab Nights is on a topic of freedom - what does it mean to be truly free?

In most cases, our desire for freedom is expressed in the search for a retreat, an escape from the routine and daily preoccupations. We want to break free from the burdens, the pressure, from the boss at work, the overdraft in the bank, to escape the political situation, the tension, the economic situation, others' judgment of us - in short, to take a little break from life, away from this. 

But if we stop for a minute and think about it, reflect on the situation, the question will arise: what is it really that we try so hard to break away, to disconnect from? 

Join us for a warm and stimulating evening of scrutinizing this topic through authentic wisdom of Kabbalah.
results.name: The Secret to Real Freedom

results.description:
Let’s schedule our first meet up and start at the very beginning of legal matters that arise when somebody decides to start a business. We’ll start our discussion with the topic

At what point of the business development you need to form a company

Founders of startup companies often wait to incorporate a company until they are confident that their concept is viable. At some point, however, an entrepreneur will need to formally incorporate a company. We’ll review the triggering events and reasons for taking the step to incorporate.

and continue with

What type of entity you should choose. Pros & cons of available business structures.

Partnerships, C corps, LLCs, and S corps differ significantly in the areas of taxation, ownership, fundraising, governance, structure, and employee compensation. The efficiency of one or another legal structure depends on the type of business and goals of its organizers. We’ll compare various forms of doing business and discuss the pros & cons of each.

Suggested format of the meeting:

I’ll start with the short presentation, cover the main legal aspects of the posted topics, and then open the floor for questions, discussions, suggestions, and other interactions between the attendees :)
results.name: What type of entity you should choose. Pros & cons of each. - legal seminar
