results.description:
Lets Kick off October in New York. It is one of the oldest cities in America, having been 400 years since the it was founded. Having buildings that date back to the 1700's and 1800's has brought not only a timeline full of famous events and infamous character but also quite a bit of superstition and myth.

Many of these stories center around the buildings and the people that used to reside there and in some cases still do. Below are five of the most haunted places in New York City and we Will Visit them  


1. Morris-Jumel Mansion - http://www.morrisjumel.org/
Morris Jumel is currently the oldest home on the island of Manhattan and was once the residence to famous New York resident Aaron Burr as well as other lesser well known historic figures. The house was built in 1765 and is most well known for being the temporary headquarters for George Washington after his army's defeat at the Battle of Brooklyn.  Who haunts this place? 
The most famous ghost (there are several who are known to haunt the mansion) at the Morris Jumel Mansion is that of Eliza Jumel who was the wife of Aaron Burr, who himself is most famous for killing Alexander Hamilton in a duel. Her haunting of the mansion is said to be because of the mysterious death of her first husband of which she was rumored to have murdered.

2. The House of Death ------Located in the West Village, one of the most picturesque neighborhoods in all of New York City, this particular building was constructed during the late 1850's. The physical address of 14 West 10th street places it on a tree lined block where one would never know had a building nicknamed the House of Death. Its most famous resident was that of Mark Twain who called this place home during the early 1900's. The building name comes both from the ghosts that haunt this building and also from the tragedy that occurred here in 1989 where prominent attorney Joel Steinberg killed his adopted daughter by beating her to death.

Who haunts this place? 
The house is known to be haunted by no less than 22 different spirits and apparitions ranging from young children, old ladies, and even a cat. Yet the most famous ghost comes in the form of Samuel Clemmons, known mostly as Mark Twain, who roams the bottom floors and basement of this building dressed head to toe in a white suit.

3. The Dakota- 
Built in 1884, this building stands as a New York City landmark and is one of the most sought after residences in all of Manhattan. The building is most known as the location that famed musician John Lennon, who was a resident, was shot and killed while exiting. The Dakota was also where the horror movie "Rosemarie's Baby" was filmed due to its creepy gothic architecture style.

Who haunts this place? 
While the ghost of John Lennon has been known to appear to residents of the building, he is not this locations most famous ghosts. This distinction falls to the ghosts of two young children who have been seen as far back as at least the 1960's. The children seem to be dressed in clothing that resembles that of the era of when the building was constructed, so the rumor is that they were once residents of the

Who haunts this place?  While not the prevailing cause of his parting, the rumor that Dylan Thomas drank himself to death at the White Horse is well known and often believed. This has not stopped his ghost from continuing to haunt his favorite watering hole even after his passing. His ghost is said to move things around in the bar as well as having been seen drinking at his favorite table before quickly disappearing. The bar helps keep his legacy alive and well by keeping a massive portrait hanging in the middle of the bar.


4.. Jefferson Market Library

Built originally to serve as a fire tower lookout in 1833, this building was expanded to serve as a courthouse in 1877. It was also the location for New York City's first night court due to its central location in the city's entertainment district at the time. This also caused it to expand its use yet again as a woman's prison as many of the defendants being prosecuted at the night court were prostitutes. It was also home to New York's most infamous court case in which Harry Kendall Thaw was acquitted of the murder of world renowned architect Sanford White by reason of insanity. Who haunts this place?  While no specific ghost haunts this particular location, people have seen figures at night up in the top of the bell tower that is closed year round to the public. This location has also been home to female apparitions, which are known to roam the small park that used to be the location of the female only prison.

Our Meal has been upgrade to An Authentic Inhabited Haunted-Place Restaurant "Genes"  Built on a the a  Burial Ground.  David the Owner told me you can here "Disembodied Voices" ringing through the Dinning Room at night. The Restaurant will be  Brimming with ghost-hunting tips  full of spooky lore, this place  is guaranteed to raise hairs! 

We Will be dinning @ Gene"s - 


After Talking to Ghosts abound in Manhattan, and with the aid of Dr. Philip Ernest Schoenberg's extensive guide

Author "Ghost OF Manhattan" and Tour Guide 

He stated that Jekyll and Hide is A "Fake" Contrived No Ghosts there -So Will still will stop in, at the End of our tour for a Drink to Vist.

SO We Will be Dnning @ "Gene"s"  w Neighborhood Haunts Go Back 120 Years

What included ?


RT TRANSPORTATION Tour on Deluxe Motor Coach 

Admission Fees - and Tour Guide

Dinner w Tax and TIps


EVERYTHING Only $107. 00 pp

Hello! The First Half We are Uptown-On the Bus 1.. Morris-Jumel Mansion2.  The Dakota-  + 3.And a Secret Surprise Stop- 
Next We will make our Way Downtown on the Bus to the Village- Then the Haunted WalkingTour Begins-  to Jefferson Market Library, Restaurant, House of Death and Other Secret Stops- 
I Cant Review All Stops -Will Ruin the Mystic Surprises

REI'S Pitch:

Looking for great deals on great gear? Come to REI's garage sale! Open to REI members only! This sale features huge discounts on returned, experienced, and slightly damaged products. results.description:
My favorite way to describe the Gluten Free and Allergy Free Expo is trick-or-treating for Celiacs ...only without the costumes. You get a tote bag when you enter, then go from booth to booth trying samples of gluten-free products. Some vendors have items to purchase on the spot, others give out coupons or online order information.

Vendors are usually both local companies and national brands. Usually several local bakeries come, which is a great way to see their range of breads, cookies, and cupcakes. I love to taste test to see how they compare to my own baking and get ideas. We do also buy! Always good to support the local gluten-free businesses. 

There's a wide range of non-food items as well. Past shows have had gluten-free sunscreens, lotions and hair products, bamboo pillows and sheets, essential oils, eco-friendly cleaning products, gluten-free box subscription companies, and more.

The expo is on Sat. Oct 3 and Sunday Oct 4, 2015. In addition to the trade show portion, there are also classes on nutrition, cooking, and health issues.

The vendor list, classes and speakers is still developing. At this time (April) tickets are not yet available, but when they are tickets may be purchased at https://gfafexpo.com/
results.how_to_find_us: Booth 1911 for Gluten-Free Travel Group - between Sweet Note Bagels and Celiac Support Association, across the back

results.description:
Hola amigos,

Join us for a relaxing and educational Saturday afternoon to hone your photography skills during a workshop led by an experienced photographer. We encourage you to push yourself to the limits of your current photo skills and imagination! During this intensive two-hour workshop, we will give you photography fundamentals, incorporating theory, techniques, photo assignments and a critique sessions. For the majority of the tour, we will use Spanish with the use of English to only help clarify concepts and elaborate comments and ideas. With the guidance of our expert photographer, we will learn how to make compelling and memorable magazine-quality photographs—skills you can use to document travel experiences and special moments or simply capture great images of your family!

After the photo workshop, we'll head to the High Line where an experienced volunteer from the Friends of the High Line foundation will greet us (en español) and tell us the history of this amazing public park built on a historic freight rail line elevated above the streets on Manhattan’s West Side. Then we'll start a Walk & Talk through the park while completing photo assignments under the guidance of our experienced photographer. Finally the group will go to Chelsea Market to indulge ourselves with mouth watering Mexican tacos.

****************************************************************


***************************************************************


This unique photo-tour includes various activities including:

• Photography fundamentals workshop

• High Line visit and tour

• Walk & Talk

• Photo assignments: capturing images and telling stories with your images

• Visit to the Chelsea Market

**************************************************************

WHO: Anybody interested in learning about photography, culture and Spanish

WHEN: October, Saturday 3rd at 10:30 am

WHERE: Easy Español and the High Line park

HOW: The meeting point will be Easy Español

WHY: Because we want to have fun, learn new things and meet great people

HOW MUCH: $29

**************************************************************

Allá nos vemos!

Jorge

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Join us for a full Saturday of social Wikipedia editing at MoMA (drop-in any time!), during which we will create, update, and improve Wikipedia articles pertaining to the lives and works of Latin American artists.

The WikiArte (Wiki Arte y Cultura Latinoamerica) edit-a-thon is a global campaign to improve Wikipedia's coverage of Latin American arts and culture and to counter geocultural systemic bias on Wikipedia. 

The Museum of Modern Art and Fundacion Cisneros/Colección Patricia Phelps de Cisneros are uniting with international allies to focus on the lives and works of Latin American artists, architects and designers. 


With keystone events scheduled for October 3 in New York City and elsewhere, the campaign aims to further similar goals to Art+Feminism.


All are invited, with no specialized knowledge of the subject or Wikipedia editing experience required. A brief overview of the basics of Wikipedia editing will be given at the start of the edit-a-thon. Please bring your laptop and power cord; we will have library resources, WiFi, and a list of suggested topics on hand.

Page on Eventbrite:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/wikiarte-edit-a-thon-tickets-18545269400


Page on Wikipedia:


</a><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/WikiArte/MoMA_2015">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/WikiArte/MoMA_2015

Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.

Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: Gotham Archery has reserved space for us from 11:00am to 1:00pm. Those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer at the regular range rate.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at Gotham Archery, you will have to take a safety & intro lesson class from the range staff and demonstrate safe shooting. No exceptions. Please arrive 15 minutes early; the class will start promptly at 11:00am.

Public Transportation: Gotham Archery is located at 480 Baltic St (Brooklyn, NY 11217) in Gowanus. It's a few blocks south-west of the Atlantic Av-Barclays Ctr train station. The 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, B, D, N, Q and R trains all stop there.

By car from LI:You can take the LIE, Northern State or Southern State to either Jackie Robinson or the BQE.  Set your GPS to 480 Baltic Street, NY, 11217.  The parking on Sat. AM isn't bad at all: you may have to circle the block once or twice.  The building is painted in a somber yellow ochre.

BUT: please consider car pooling or training it: the drive is awful; the train is lovely.  Most LI LIRR stations suspend parking fees on Sat and Sun.

You change at Jamaica and get in at the Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn-- walk south for about 7-8 minutes to Baltic -- go right.  Gotham is on the left.  The first time you walk here, you should have your GPS active.


 Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rate: $20 for two hours of shooting, $5 for equipment (plus sales tax). These discounts only apply during official club hours.

 Club Equipment: At this time we cannot guarantee there will be club equipment to borrow, so please plan accordingly. One of us will post in the comments if that changes.

 See you on the shooting line!

Join us as we explore what was once the playgrounds of all things gang and mob related on this 2.5 hour walking tour. Stroll through historic downtown neighborhoods as you peer into their dark past. Visit famous sites of killings, movies, and infamous crimes.

Peer into New York's dark past and uncover hidden secrets when you visit places ruled by some of the city's most powerful gangs and mobs. Head to Little Italy, once the heart of a tight community of Italian immigrants, to hear stories about mob activities and visit notorious spots. You’ll also explore the little-known history of the Chinese migration to New York, and the dominance of dangerous street gangs and underground opium dens, as well as the ruthless gangs in the infamous Five Points area, and what became of them. Along the way you’ll stop to see historic sites, sample the local fare and discover hidden stories waiting to be revealed.

results.description:
So far in our discussion of these Factors of Awakening, we've seen that when we are steadily mindful and investigate our thoughts and mind states with discernment, our energy and effort and persistence in practice are more alive and focused.

To move on to the next factor of JOY from this mindful, curious, energetic state, we first need to define and understand the meaning of JOY in this context. Most often we think of joy in terms of the pleasant feelings of comfort or well-being that we experience through our senses. In the Pali language, the term often translated as this definition of joy is "sukha," that is closer to what we would call the feeling of "happiness."  

For our exploration of JOY as a factor of awakening the translation of the Pali word "piti" is more apt. It is understood as a mental state beyond our sensory experience, and is sometimes described in the same way the "flow state" is described. Meditative joy is not found in outward, worldly rewards, but in the focused and concentrated mental state itself. We meditate for its own sake, not for some other purpose.

When our minds are in a state of JOY, we lean more often and more consistently toward the positive aspects of experience; experiences that are beautiful, wholesome, pleasant, and satisfying.  We also notice that our perceptions of unpleasant things become neutralized and we may even be able to see the "silver lining" or inherent lessons that are present in every experience. There is also an increased overall feeling of pleasure and happiness and a emotional resilience to adversity.

The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds. The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: The Seven Factors of Awakening - Joy

results.description:
Do you love mankind's furry little friends?  Let's help keep them fed and healthy.  I didn't know pet food pantries existed and I was excited to help when I found out.  =)  The pantry is small but directly serves over 760 animals!  Volunteers will be packing up bags with donated items for client pickup.

About HVPFP:  The Hudson Valley Pet Food Pantry was founded in 2010 as a non-profit organization. It was established to help individuals and families who need assistance with feeding their pets because of job loss or other hardship. We offer assistance to fixed-income senior citizens, the disabled, veterans, and others who qualify because they lack the financial resources to properly feed their pets.  The HVPFP also assists animal shelters and rescue groups as the quantity of our food supplies permits.  We distribute food in boxes, bags and cans for dogs, cats, birds, rabbits and some other domestic pets  As of January 1, 2015, each month we are helping keep more than 760 animals at home and out of shelters by providing free pet food to 300 families.  The Hudson Valley Pet Food Pantry serves residents of Westchester, Putnam, Rockland and Dutchess Counties who meet our eligibility requirements. The pantry is located in the lower level of the Ridgeview Congregational Church, White Plains, New York.

results.description:
Come, sit, stay, and celebrate  Central Park and its dog community!

My Dog Loves Central Park Fair

Saturday, October 3, 2015

11:00 am – 3:00 pm

Naumburg Bandshell (mid-Park at 72nd Street)

Free; RSVP to let us know you're coming!

</a> Come, sit, stay, and celebrate Central Park and its dog community! Tails will be wagging as Central Park Conservancy and its program for dog lovers, Central Park Paws, host you and your canine for an afternoon of contests, training tips, games, and more.

This event is hosted by <a href="http://www.centralparknyc.org/about/programs/central-park-paws/">Central Park Paws, a program of Central Park Conservancy. Central Park Paws encourages dog owners to become stewards of the Park and serves as the connector between the dog community, Central Park, and the Conservancy.

Open to all ages. The Fair is an on-leash event.

Schedule of Events on the Main Stage

11:00 am – Welcome with emcee Kevin Character

11:30 am – Dog Training Workshop with Ian Phillips of See Spot Run

12:00 pm – Game on Stage: Tricks for Treats

12:30 pm – Dog Training Workshop with Ian Phillips

1:00 pm – Game on Stage: Musical Mutts

1:30 pm – Dog Training Workshop with Ian Phillips

2:00 pm – Game on Stage: Dancing with your Dog

2:45 pm – Paws Promenade: World’s Largest Dog Selfie (#centralparkpaws)

ALL-DAY ACTIVITIES AND SERVICES

Agility for Everyone

Try out your dog's agility on the obstacle course. Facilitated by Biscuits & Bath.

Bark Boutique

Purchase T-shirts, hats, travel bowls, and other merchandise to support Paws and Central Park Conservancy. Join or renew your Central Park Conservancy membership to keep the Park clean and green for you and your pup to enjoy. Find out when fun things are happening in the Park when you sign up for monthly Central Park Paws and Conservancy updates.

Canine Good Citizen Evaluations

Take the AKC Canine Good Citizen test with your dog. A Fair Shake for Youth will be hosting evaluations throughout the day. If your dog can perform basic commands without treats, walk through a crowd, pass another dog and be separated from you without distress your dog may be a Canine Good Citizen. All dogs must present a rabies tag or certificate to be tested. Please click here for more information on the test, and to see if your dog might be qualified!

Dog Licenses

The New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene will be on site to process your new and renewing dog licenses while you wait!

Hound Hydration Station

A water break for your furry friend.

Microchipping

Have your dog microchipped by veterinarians from the Mayor’s Alliance for NYC’s Animals.

Park Paws-itivity, Pooch Plinko, and Paws Scavenger Hunt

Meet Central Park Paws volunteers, and learn how this program of the Conservancy helps keep the Park a clean and friendly place for dog owners and dogs alike. Win prizes at the Woof Wheel and Pooch Plinko games. Join a scavenger hunt and use investigative skills while learning fun facts about Central Park.

Snack Attack

Let your pup sample fresh food and treats at the Wellness TruFood Wagon and Freshpet Food Truck.

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

PLEASE RSVP RESPONSIBLY.  IT TAKES MONTHS TO GET A RESERVATION AT THIS PLACE, SO YOU ARE GOING TO HAVE TO RECONFIRM THAT YOU WILL DEFINITELY, ABSOLUTELY, WITHOUT A DOUBT BE GOING WHEN WE GET CLOSER TO THE EVENT IF THERE ARE PEOPLE ON THE WAITING LIST.  

THIS IS A "CASH ONLY" EVENT.  IF YOU DON'T BRING CASH, YOU WILL NEED TO FIND AN ATM TO GET SOME.  WE WILL USE THE "x1.3" WAY TO FIGURE OUT THE BILL. CHECK OUT THE GROUP TIPPING POLICY HERE.

Yes, I said BOTTOMLESS BRUNCH!!  

Calle Ocho serves unlimited sangria when you purchase a brunch entree. Prices range from $18 to $32 (that serves 2 people) for entrees. Check out the menu, and get ready for a fantastic, and what will be sure to be a FUN (with not only a capital F, but a capital UN as well!) brunch!  The free sangria is served while we are still eating, so we don't need to rush through the meal (although they do have a 3 hour time limit).  


The reservation time is for 12 noon.  Please arrive by 11:50 at the latest.  And afterwards, we can walk over to Central Park and maybe the leaves will be changing already by then.

Here are their brunch "rules"

BRUNCH HOUSE RULES 

• Please enjoy one glass of sangria at a time. Don’t worry, there is plenty more where that came from!

• Complimentary sangria is served during the course of your meal, not forever (unfortunately)! If that last bite of burrito has been sitting on your plate for 3 hours, you’re kind of toeing the line of “forever."

• If one person gets cut off, so does the rest of your table. So please ask your boyfriend to save his awesome tabletop dancing skills for another day.

• Management reserves the right to discontinue serving any patron at any time. (Boring, we know -- our lawyers made us put this one in).

• Sangria is served in 20 oz. glasses, so don’t be sad if you don’t get to all the flavors. We still think you’re a champ!

• No sangria is allowed outside the restaurant.

• Please don’t forget your children here. We WILL put them to work.

• We encourage our guests to enjoy a fun, leisurely sangria brunch, but please also be mindful of our additional reservations. Your fellow brunchers would also like to enjoy the sangria (and perhaps a bite to eat).

• Please drink responsibly.

HAVE FUN AND ENJOY!

This event will be for My New Friend members only.  No guests.  So if you have someone that you want to come, they will need to sign up for the group and RSVP for themselves.

results.description:
Introduction to Figure Drawing for Beginners. 

This four-hour session is designed to introduce beginners (and people who consider themselves beginners) to figure drawing. 

The Session: This session will cover the basic theories artists use to draw the human figure. 

We will work from a live model for the entire session in this amazing room!

Introduction: Drawing Form. The first 30 minutes of the session will discuss our approach to treating the human figure as a series of simple shapes to more easily represent it. We will learn to solve basic drawing problems.

Gesture Drawing: What is it and why do we practice it? Students will approach gesture drawing two different ways.  This is an essential part of figure drawing. 

"Great class! Surpassed all my expectations. As a beginner, I was amazed at how much I was able to learn...I had a blast & highly recommend this intro course to others." Lou

The Skeleton: Students will learn the basic measurements of the human skeleton. Using a worksheet to follow a large diagram we will go through the entire figure to give students a functional understanding of the skeleton.

Figure Drawing: What is our goal when drawing 5-10 minute poses? There is a great deal we can do in these medium length poses if only we set ourselves goals in the time allotted. We will practice two different approaches to these poses. 

"This was an excellent experience for beginning figure drawing. Simon provided a vast amount of knowledge regarding the essentials of drawing the human figure. Would definitely recommend this intro course to others." Robert 


Muscle Groups: Students will be introduced to the large muscle groups of the body in a similar manner to the skeleton above. 

Long Poses: We will practice at least two long poses. Many of us run out of things to draw in longer poses. We grow bored and stop “thinking” while we work. With a proper focus we will find that these long poses will actually feel very brief to us. 

Critique: Drawings of willing students will be shown and discussed. We will talk about successes and what we can do to improve in the future. The goal of a good critique is not to criticize students but to point out future goals where they can improve. This allows them to leave the session eager to continue drawing and improving.

Material requirements: 14x17 inch sketch or drawing pad (not newsprint.) 2H, HB and 4B pencils. An eraser and pencil sharpener. 


If you have any questions please feel free to email me at simon (at) drawingnewyork.com

Instructor: Simon Levenson teaches drawing at The National Arts Club, The Museum of the City of New York and The Morgan Library and Museum. He is the founder of Drawing New York.
results.name: (Sold Out) Introduction to Figure Drawing for Beginners

results.description:
** This class is for anyone who is completely new to improv and have been afraid to try it out. **

** You're welcome to stay and watch the Level 2 class that's happening right after this class ends. **

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

Anyone and everyone is welcome! 

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

-----------------------------------------------

About Dewey Chaffee

Dewey has more than 20 years of improvisation experience. He spent 23 years perfecting his skills as an improv performer for the Walt Disney Company. He's also appeared on Nickelodeon Television and worked as their audience warm up guy for several seasons of TV production.

Currently, he and his husband perform a live improvised comedy drag show called "The Lady Winifred and Didi Show."
results.name: Intro to Improv [LEVEL 1]

Joomlapolis has been with the Joomla community from the very beginning... https://www.joomlapolis.com/

here is a note from their site in 2005..


"Joomlapolis - the polis (means town/city in Greek) of Joomla - will showcase all its projects. To this end, the Community Builder suite is used throught this site in order to facilitate the creation and growth of our online community. This will be self evident throughout the various transactions and day to day activities of this community. The registration process, the user profiling, user lists, the forums, the PMS and other features are based on the latest Community Builder suite and some of its integrated/collaborating components."

Here is a note from 2015...with regards to how Community Builder works with Joomla...

"The Joomla 3.4.3 announcement came only a few days after the project's 3.4.2 release quickly addressing some buggers that slipped through. Joomla community gets an A for addressing these issues.

During this process we have been fixing CB 2.0.9 issues and also verifying that everything still works great with the latest Joomla versions.

Community Builder[masked] is available and it has 3 new features and it also fixes 16 bugs (see forum discussion for full changelog)."


I look forward to meeting Nick, and showing Nick our strong user group in New Jersey! Come and join us for a great afternoon!

results.description:
UPDATE: the weather looks crappy! I have moved us into the Whole Foods in Columbus Circle right near where we would've met anyway. I will have a Meetup sign on the table and try to snag us some space. See you there!

Greetings all,

Reports of my disappearance have been greatly exaggerated. I do live in New Haven now though I am in NYC quite often and would like to come down and have a big meetup once a month and see just how many of you perpetually apathetic (how do you say that in Chinese?) members I can drag out of hiding to come and actually be social and speak some Mandarin.

So, weather permitting, we're meeting in Central Park in a few weekends for a gathering and picnic on the grass. Bring snacks or drinks to share if you like, no booze or at least be discrete. If this works well, we'll make it a regular thing, indoors as the weather gets colder. If this turns out to be too cold or the weather isn't good, we'll go to that Sony public atrium at 55th and Madison but in a few weeks I will post that once we see the weather report.

For all the newcomers, welcome! If you've never come to one of our meetups before, come! I mean, you joined the meetup, you must be at least a little interested. We speak only Chinese, no English, and we chat about whatever comes to mind. Look forward to seeing you all,

Dan

results.description:
** Saturday Afternoon Open Play/Clinic Combos**

We now offer, Beginner, Intermediate and occasionally Advanced, Saturday afternoon Combined Open Play/Clinics for the UNBELIEVABLE PRICE of $14.00 for a 3 hr. Session!

An Open Play/Clinic! What’s that?........It is our unique creation! Three hours of Open Play and Clinic combined! Here’s how it works. 3 teams of 8 players each alternate playing games on one of our 2 main courts at Brandeis H.S. (84th st. bet Columbus & Amsterdam) Now get this, while the third team is out, instead of sitting around, that team gets a clinic (8 players to one coach) on our back court at Brandeis with a top instructor. When the two teams finish their game on the main court, one comes off for instruction. Meanwhile, the players that just received instruction take what they just learned and use it in the next game. This rotation continues for 3 hrs! It is a great way to meet new players and improve your skills at the same time.  It is an absolutely unbelievable deal!

***Please note- RSVP'g on Meetup will not reserve your spot. Please go to our website to sign up.*** A credit card payment is required to reserve your space.

results.description:
In the 1950s and 1960s, folk music blossomed in New York City, especially in Greenwich Village, where clubs and coffee houses showcased singers like Pete Seeger and Odetta and nurtured a generation of newcomers, including Bob Dylan, Judy Collins, Dave Van Ronk, Ramblin' Jack Elliott, and Peter, Paul and Mary. The multi-media exhibition, Folk City: New York and the Folk Music Revival, featuring original instruments, handwritten lyrics, and video and film footage, traces the roots of the revival, its growth in New York, its major players, and its impact on American politics and culture during the tumultuous 1960s. 

Suggested Admission

Adults $14

Seniors $10

Subway

#6 to 103rd St.

#2 or 3 to CPW/110th St.

Bus

M1, M2, M3, M4 or M106 to 104th St.

After the exhibit, we will head over to:

Moustache Restaurant

1621 Lexington Ave. at 102nd St.

Their light and airy dining room boasts comfortable padded chairs and burnished copper table tops. An outdoor café allows for dining outside when the weather is nice. The big attraction, however, is the fantastic Middle Eastern food served up at this establishment. The oven-baked pitzas are done on pita bread and come with appropriate Middle Eastern toppings. If you are tired of the same old pizza, this is the place to come. Choose a pie with ground lamb, onion, tomato, parsley and spices, or one with walnuts, dried yogurt, onions and olive oil. There are kebabs, sandwiches, and salads.


http://moustachepitza.com/specialties.shtm

A $2.00 fee is requested to help defray the organizer dues payments.

results.name: Visit the Folk City exhibit at the Museum of the City of NY & lunch @ Moustache

ALL players need to bring a white and black t-shirt and  ball.


It's a large field and some players may need the option to sub. If you're a dedicated goalkeeper let us know - Intermediate level up.


****************************************************************

DETAILS:

• Played in a friendly environment. Pass the ball have fun.

• No rough tackles or play. Players are expected to bring a positive attitude, no screaming at/or berating team mates.

•  BRING A BALL. If you hit a ball into the river, you'll need to replace it!  If there aren't any dedicated goalkeepers playing, we rotate in goal every 5 mins.

• No metal cleats. Only turf or molded cleats.

• If you arrive late, pls wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow, and it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


Payment goes toward field permit, equipment and fees.

See you at the pitch!


Note: The is a 2/3 regulation size field with full size goals. Not suitable for beginner level or inexperienced players.

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.

results.description:
Hey all. This month we're reading Annihilation by Jeff Vandermeer. 

"Area X has been cut off from the rest of the continent for decades. Nature has reclaimed the last vestiges of human civilization. The first expedition returned with reports of a pristine, Edenic landscape; the second expedition ended in mass suicide, the third expedition in a hail of gunfire as its members turned on one another. The members of the eleventh expedition returned as shadows of their former selves, and within weeks, all had died of cancer. In Annihilation, the first volume of Jeff VanderMeer's Southern Reach trilogy, we join the twelfth expedition.
The group is made up of four women: an anthropologist; a surveyor; a psychologist, the de facto leader; and our narrator, a biologist. Their mission is to map the terrain, record all observations of their surroundings and of one anotioner, and, above all, avoid being contaminated by Area X itself.
They arrive expecting the unexpected, and Area X delivers--they discover a massive topographic anomaly and life forms that surpass understanding--but it's the surprises that came across the border with them and the secrets the expedition members are keeping from one another that change everything"

Meals, discussion, and voting on the next book to follow. Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Find your inner peace in the mist of chaotic city life. We experience stressful and painful things in our lives, these things sure are difficult, beneath the tears and hurt, there still remains peace and love inside us. If you are looking to get better, or find balances in your life, come join this meetup and let your inner peace take over, you will be amazed.


This Saturday afternoon, we will be having a meditation/relaxation session by listening to a type of traditional music originated from rural part of eastern China, which is mellow, melodious yet very emotive and powerful. Just close your eyes and let your mind flow with these beautiful ancient melodies, get in the zone, let go of those emotional tensions that have been bottling up, cry a little if you feel like to.


The meditation/relaxation session starts with 10 minutes of guided meditation, then 30 minutes of music, after that we spend approx 45minutes or so introducing ourselves to each other, discussing and sharing difficulties or happiness in our lives if you choose to. We spend the last 15-20 minutes relaxing to the music again.

Guidelines:

Please arrive 10-15 minutes early, we will promptly start at 2pm,  door will be closed to prevent disturbance once the meditation is in session.

We meet in the downstairs conference room, if you can't find it simply ask a front desk person where the Meditation Group Meeting is as you enter the library.

Bring your own water to drink.

Bring your own yoga mat if you wish to sit on the floor, or there are chairs in the room you can sit on.

Please RSVP responsibly, only sign up for this meetup if you have a true intention to attend and be on time.  If you must cancel, please kindly hit the "change" button switch to "no", so other people on the waitlist can move up.

Cost:  $15 (cash) to cover group incurred expenses and organizing fees, it will be collected at the meeting.
results.name: Self Healing Circle and Guided Meditation/Relaxation Therapy with Music

results.description:
This Event: 

The aim of this weekly event is to offer a place where Python developers and learners can come and ask questions or give help. 

Individuals of all programming skill levels are welcome. 

It is suggested that you bring your own laptop. If you don't have access to a laptop and want to attend, please let Paul Logston know and he will see about getting you a laptop for the day.

This event is free. 

This event is not a tutorial. Tutorials hosted by Learn Python NYC are labeled as tutorials.

Resources:

Here are some learning resources and free text editor / IDE suggestions.

https://github.com/logston/NYCPythonSOH/blob/master/resources.rst 

Detailed Directions to us:

results.description:
THIS IS A FREE PANEL TALK.


TOPIC  :  Understanding Genius.

http://www.helixcenter.org/roundtables/understanding-genius/

Schopenhauer defined genius in relation to the more conventional quality of talent. “Talent hits a target others miss. Genius hits a target no one sees.” Is originality indeed the sine qua non of genius? Is there, following Kant, a radical separation of the aesthetic genius from the brilliant scientific mind? What further distinctions might be made between different types of genius? If “The Child is father of the Man,” why don’t child prodigies always grow up to become adult geniuses?


AFTER the Talk : Lets gather and walk to a near-by pub for a pint or a cozy coffee house to share our initial responses/thoughts/feelings to the content of the Talk  for about ~30-45 minutes.

Jorge  ( I look like my photo)

[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Arrive early for seating. No worries, if you run late. Afterwards, lets meet for some coffee or a pint. My cell is 917 613.9736
results.name: Understanding Genius   ( a free Talk)

Lower East Side, nr East River Park. 8-10 min walk from Delancey Street F train, head east along Houston, the field is south of Houston. Map here.

Details:

1) Teams divide into equal ability - players are welcome to signup with friends.

2) No metal cleats. Turf shoes / molded cleats only. Wear proper Soccer attire.

3) Played in a fun and chill environment. Rough play, tackles, or sliding are not tolerated.


4) If no dedicated goalkeepers, all players need to rotate in goal. Full size goals.


5) If you arrive late wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow- it's not fair to those that arrive on time.

results.description:
Schopenhauer defined genius in relation to the more conventional quality of talent. “Talent hits a target others miss. Genius hits a target no one sees.” Is originality indeed the sine qua non of genius? Is there, following Kant, a radical separation of the aesthetic genius from the brilliant scientific mind? What further distinctions might be made between different types of genius? If “The Child is father of the Man,” why don’t child prodigies always grow up to become adult geniuses?

UNDERSTANDING
GENIUS


STEVE HSU
REX JUNG
DARRIN MCMAHON
JOANNE RUTHSATZ
DEAN KEITH SIMONTON

Saturday, October 3, 2015, 2:30 pm

The Marianne & Nicholas Young Auditorium of
The New York Psychoanalytic Society & Institute 
247 East 82nd Street, NYC

Free and open to the public 
    Seating is on a first-come, first-serve basis
No registration required!

STEVE HSU is Vice-President for Research and Professor of Theoretical Physics at Michigan State University, where he oversees over $500 million in annual research expenditures. Educated at Caltech and Berkeley, he was a Harvard Junior Fellow and held professorships at Yale University and the University of Oregon. Hsu was founder and CEO of SafeWeb, an information security startup acquired by Symantec. He is a scientific advisor to BGI and a member of its Cognitive Genomics Lab. Hsu has developed new algorithms for genomic prediction using large scale datasets.

REX JUNG received his training in clinical psychology, specializing in neuropsychology, at the University of New Mexico, in Albuquerque. He completed an internship at Baylor College of Medicine in the Departments of Neurosurgery and Behavioral Medicine, and postdoctoral training at the University of New Mexico in Psychiatry Research. He has been on the Neurosurgery faculty at the University of New Mexico since 2008, where he splits his time between neuroimaging research and holding neuropsychology clinics with neurosurgical patients. He studies both brain disease and what the brain does well—a field of research known as “positive neuroscience. His research is designed to relate behavioral measures, including intelligence, personality, and creativity, to brain function and structure in healthy, neurological, and psychiatric subjects. He has published research articles across a wide range of disciplines, including traumatic brain injury, lupus, schizophrenia, intelligence, creativity, and genius. His research has been funded by the National Institutes of Health, the National Endowment for the Arts, DARPA, and the John Templeton Foundation. He is on the Editorial Boards of Intelligence, PLoS ONE, and Frontiers. He will be editing a forthcoming book with Cambridge University Press (with Oshin Vartanian) entitled “Handbook of the Neuroscience of Creativity.”
  DARRIN MCMAHON is the Mary Brinsmead Wheelock professor at Dartmouth College, and formerly the Ben Weider Professor and Distinguished Research Professor at Florida State University. Born in Carmel, California, and educated at the University of California, Berkeley and Yale, where he received his PhD in 1998, McMahon is the author of Enemies of the Enlightenment: The French Counter-Enlightenment and the Making of Modernity (Oxford University Press, 2001) and Happiness: A History (Atlantic Monthly Press, 2006), which has been translated into twelve languages, and was awarded Best Books of the Year honors for 2006 by the New York Times, The Washington Post, the Library Journal, and Slate Magazine. I In 2013, McMahon completed a history of the idea of genius and the genius figure, Divine Fury: A History of Genius, published with Basic Books. He is also the editor, with Ryan Hanley, of The Enlightenment: Critical Concepts in Historical Studies, 5 vols. (Routledge, 2009); with Samuel Moyn, of Rethinking Modern European Intellectual History (Oxford University Press, 2014); and with Joyce Chaplin of Genealogies of Genius (forthcoming 2016 with Palgrave). McMahon has taught as a visiting scholar at Columbia University, New York University, Yale University, the University of Rouen, the École Normale Supérieur, École des Hautes Études, and the University of Potsdam. His writings have appeared in such publications as the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Boston Globe, New York Times Book Review, Slate, Washington Post, The New Republic, and the Literary Review.
JOANNE RUTHSATZ is Assistant Professor of Psychology at The Ohio State University, Mansfield. She graduated from Bowling Green State University with a BA in psychology, receiving Phi Beta Kappa. She completed her PhD in Experimental Psychology at Case Western Reserve University. Training on the Mental Retardation Research Grant, she studied the full range of human cognitive ability. Her research interests include discovering the genetic link between autism and the extraordinary talent displayed by child prodigies. Her forthcoming book is titled The Prodigy’s Cousin: The Family Link Between Autism and Extraordinary Talent.

DEAN KEITH SIMONTON is Distinguished Professor of Psychology at the University of California, Davis, he received his 1975 PhD in Social Psychology from Harvard University. His research program spans various questions associated with genius, creativity, leadership, talent, and aesthetics. Simonton’s curriculum vita lists more than 500 publications, including 13 books, namely: Genius, Creativity, and Leadership; Why Presidents Succeed; Scientific Genius; Psychology, Science, and History; Greatness; Genius and Creativity; Origins of Genius; Great Psychologists and Their Times; Creativity in Science; Genius 101; Great Flicks; Social Science of Cinema; and, most recently, The Wiley Handbook of Genius. Simonton received the William James Book Award, Sir Francis Galton Award for Outstanding Contributions to the Study of Creativity, the Rudolf Arnheim Award for Outstanding Achievement in Psychology and the Arts, the Henry A. Murray Award for “distinguished contributions to the study of individual lives and whole persons,” the Joseph B. Gittler Award for “the most scholarly contribution to the philosophical foundation of psychological knowledge,” the Distinguished Scientific Contributions to Media Psychology Award, the Theoretical Innovation Prize in Personality and Social Psychology, the George A. Miller Outstanding Article Award, the E. Paul Torrance and President’s Awards from the National Association for Gifted Children, and the Robert S. Daniel Award for Four-Year College/University Teaching. His next book project, tentatively titled The Psychology of Civilization: The Genius as the Creator of History, hopes to integrate the results from his lifelong research program, focusing on creative genius.
results.name: UNDERSTANDING GENIUS (Helix)

Monthly meetings are held on the 1st Saturday of every month from 2:30 PM to 4:00 PM at the LGBT Community Center, followed by a convivial Coffee & Desert at a nearby local restaurant. The group provides a warm & friendly, welcoming, caring, SAFE, non-discriminatory environment for everyone who lives, works or plays in the New York City area.

$5 (more if/less if) suggested donation to help defray room-rental cost

results.description:
You are invited on Saturday, October 3, 2015 at 2:30 PM to the Masonic Philosophical Society for our next hosted discussion and study. Each month a different topic, ranging from philosophy and science to religion and metaphysics, is discussed and debated. This group, which is open to the public, is where non-members can learn more about Freemasonry, as well as meet local Freemasons.

Study Topic
October's topic will be conducted by Brother Maryone Lloyd on a study of Freemasonry: What is the light in the darkness and it's correlation to humanity's place in the Universe? After a short lecture, a discussion and debate by the group will follow.

Is our quest for enlightenment both metaphorical and literal? Roughly only 5% of the Universe is visible to our eyes. Are we looking to unlock the secrets and shed light on the remaining 95% of dark matter and dark energy to "enlighten" ourselves and the Universe? Freemasonry seeks to "bring light" to mankind through knowledge for the perfection of humanity. Could Freemasonry be the light in the darkness?

Directions:
[masked]th Ave Whitestone, NY 11357

Mission Statement
The Masonic Philosophical Society embraces the concept of learning, not for school, but for life, and believes that all men, who seek it, deserve access to continued education. We further embrace the concept of a community environment, where ideas can be shared and debated in an open forum. From the seven liberal arts to the arcane, we seek to gain and to share the knowledge that is the legacy of mankind.

More Resources
Website: http://www.philosophicalsociety.org

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/masonicphilosophicalsociety

Learn more about Freemasonry: http://www.co-masonry.org
results.name: Light in the darkness:what is its correlation to our place in the universe?

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email. 


(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>) 


----------------------------------------------------------------

Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.


These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful.


You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on their own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor. Contact: [masked],[masked] for more information about Isha USA or this session.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog
results.name: Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-FREE Class-(Online Webinar)

results.description:
I keep an eye on the weather and the field.  In the case of inclement weather - I try to make a determination as early as possible - preferably 24+ hours in advance, or by noon the day of if it's still questionable.  If we are not meeting, I will actually cancel the event page and send out an email.  If you are not signed up to receive emails, check the site, or text me[masked]


Basic Ground Rules for Participation


• no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc.   If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF.  If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...).  If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.



What is Ultimate Frisbee?  In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee.  You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.

results.description:
Meet on the american football field (near the entrance close to the public restrooms)!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 3:30. We typically start 20-30 minutes after 3:30. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

results.description:
For some reason as Fall approaches I always promise myself to read more. Hopefully with others I will be more motivated so I decided to bring back and revamp the book club.

As you may have guessed, to start, it will have a Brooklyn theme. Our first selection will be one of my favorite books A Tree Grows in Brooklyn by Betty Smith.

Description from wikipedia:

A Tree Grows in Brooklyn is a 1943 novel written by Betty Smith. The story focuses on an impoverished but aspirational third-generation Irish-American adolescent girl and her family in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, New York City, during the first two decades of the 20th century. The book was an immense success.

For our first meeting we will meet at the Hollow Nickel conveniently located near Atlantic Terminal. Hollow Nickel has a full bar and also food available.

Hopefully the weather will be nice enough for us to seat in their spacious backyard. Just in case here is my cell[masked] 2767.

results.description:
This is it. The World Championships. This is the most action-packed, legendary tournament League of Legends has ever seen. All of the teams look so competitive, the west is the best it has ever been - do we have a chance!?

Watch with us and enjoy happy hour throughout the event! Food is NOT served at the venue, but you can bring food in or order from outside for pickup at the bar!

This event is all ages, but please, don't mess this up for the rest of us. If you cannot legally buy alcohol, do not attempt to purchase alcohol. Do instead enjoy some non-alcoholic refreshments to support the bar and let them know how much fun we have here at Libations!


This Saturday is the 3rd day of group stages, and here is the lineup: EDG v SKT
H2K v BKT
LGD v KTR
ORG v TSM
IG v C9
AHQ v FNC

REMINDER: This is a rebroadcast; let's try to make this a spoiler free zone - if you want to talk about the results of a game that hasn't been played yet, make sure everyone around you is ok with spoilers. Riot has buffed us! RSVP here and check in with us to receive a cool skin code! I'll give you a hint, it's not the same code you may or may not have received for any other summer split event. <3
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/12SOkZOfmndsD5KYgK5GGogcqkAkc4FN9tb9sNH1Lbbw/viewform

With Love and Poro Snax,
NYC League of Legends.

results.description:
Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

4:00 - Show up early, stake out a spot and either socialize or get a jump on writing.
4:15 - Start. Introductions, and we'll share what we're working on.
4:30 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!
5:30- Brief follow up. People are encouraged to share experiences & ideas, network or take off as they like.

If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: Milk and Honey Cafe located at 1119 Newkirk Ave. The closest train station is Newkirk Plaza on the Q line. Walk 3 block down Newkirk Avenue until you reach Westminster Road. We are sitting at the table in the back.

SOME TIPS:

Laptops are welcome. Remember to charge your laptop ahead of time.

Please buy something to support this organic cafe. It would make the owner smile.

Come on time! If you come late, we will have already started.
Bring headphones if you don't want outside noise distraction.

RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.

Don't know where to begin, read this.

http://gaiateabrew.com/leonbell/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Mini-Guide-to-Writing.pdf
results.how_to_find_us: http://www.milkandhoneycafeny.com
results.name: NYC Shut Up & Write Meetup! - Brooklyn

results.description:
This is a class in technique although, when you've conquered a song technically, then I will coach musicality and performance. Class size is limited. Fee is $20/per. You may audit the class once (without participating) for $10. Let me know when you sign up if that's your intention.

    People at the front desk are helpful and friendly and the Cafe on the floor has great coffee and cookies, sandwiches, <a>pizza</a>, etc.

    I've been asked to post this:

Dear Members:  I am Mr. Harrington's agent/rep. Mr. Harrington teaches privately coaching established actors and singers. For years his private rate has been $120/hr for this service. He started teaching through Meetup earlier this year and has as his goal to bring professional level instruction to the public at a rate that leaves no one behind. This demands tight scheduling of both his time and the room rental with Ripley-Grier Studios.For these reasons, I will be insisting to him that "no shows" be dropped from the group. The policy is this: If you RSVP you better show up. If you cancel you better do this by 4:00 pm the previous day.A word to the wise...Michael T. Harvey

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
